Title: CRWR_V 599 (6) Thesis
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: CCST_V 500 (3) Seminar in Interdisciplinary Frameworks in Museum and Curatorial Studies
Description: Theoretical and historical foundations of visual representations and expressive culture. It explores the history of museums and galleries, and changes in the meaning of art and material culture as debates about cultural property intensify. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: CCST_V 501 (3) Seminar in Contemporary Contextual Issues for Museums and Curatorial Practice
Description: An examination of broad social and political issues that confront curators and museum professionals who construct representations in museums, art galleries and other sites of public display. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: CCST_V 502 (3) Case Studies in Museum and Gallery Exhibitions
Description: A case study approach to analyzing museum and gallery exhibitions that are historically significant either because they raised issues and stimulated public debate, or because of radical features that proved influential on subsequent exhibitions. Course not offered every year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: CCST_V 503 (9) Graduate Practicum and Major Paper in Curatorial Studies
Description: Practical on-site teamwork to produce exhibitions or other public displays in a museum, gallery, or alternative situation, offering opportunities for comparison, collaboration, and interdisciplinarity. Students concurrently produce a major paper from the ideas and research which generate the exhibition. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: CSIS_V 200 (3) Critical Engagements in Sexuality Studies
Description: Introductory survey to sexuality studies that emphasizes how sexuality intersects with race, gender, class, ability, and geography. Recommended pre-requisite: GRSJ 101.
Title: CSIS_V 300 (3-6) Introduction to Critical Studies in Sexuality
Description: A multi-disciplinary course which provides an introduction to the study of sexuality, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, heterosexual, and transgender issues and related topics.
Title: CSIS_V 301 (3) Introduction to Trans* Studies
Description: How race, citizenship, gender, sexuality, culture and dis/ability are materially and socially constructed together to give meaning to the category trans*. (Trans*: transgender, transsexual, gender variant and other articulations.) Recommended pre-requisite: GRSJ 101.
Title: CSIS_V 450 (3-6) Topics in Critical Studies in Sexuality
Description: A thematic course, which explores current questions and issues in relation to the study of sexuality. Topics may vary from year to year.
Title: CSIS_V 490 (3-6) Directed Topics
Description: Designed to allow a student to develop an individual course of study in a specific area as approved by a faculty member affiliated with the CSIS program.
Title: CSIS_V 500 (3-6) Critical Studies in Sexuality: Multi-disciplinary Approaches
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 210 (3) Introduction to Music Education
Description: Role of music education in schools and society, including historical, philosophical, psychological, and sociological perspectives. Includes guided class observations and practice music teaching in elementary and secondary schools. Criminal Record Check required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: EDCP_V 515 (3) Education and Complexity Theory

Title: EDCP_V 520 (3) Perspectives, Practice, and Curriculum Issues in Contemporary Art Education
Description: Emphasis is placed upon the foundations and conflicting conceptions of curriculum in art education. Theory/practice issues in the development, implementation, and evaluation of art programs are explored. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 521 (3) Historical and Social Foundations of Art Education
Description: Histories of art education are examined. Social and cultural implications for art education (past and present) are explored. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 522 (3) Psychological Foundations of Art Education
Description: Psychological considerations specifically related to cognitive development in art, are explored. Implications for art education theory and practice are drawn. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 523 (3-6) Seminar in Art Education
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 524 (3) Technology, Virtual Worlds, and Digital Visual Culture in Art Education
Description: Foundations and conflicting conceptions of digital visual culture and art education. Theory and practice in the development and implementation of art education technology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 525 (3-6) Special Colloquia in Music Education
Description: The Special Colloquia in Music Education offer opportunities to critically engage with particular aspects of music education. Specfic topics vary from year to year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 526 (3-6) Theory and Principles of Music Education
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 530 (3) Curriculum Innovations in Physical Education
Description: Developing an integrated approach toward curriculum planning and instruction by examining curriculum models. Rethinking the PE curriculum. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 531 (3) Health Promotion, Wellness and Lifeskills in Outdoor Settings
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 532 (3) Theories and Dimensions of Place-Based Education: Ecohumanist, Critical, and Indigenous Lenses
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 533 (3) Health, Outdoor and Physical Experiential Education Curriculum, Pedagogy and Place in the Elementary School
Description: Concepts, skills, and dispositions necessary to teach health, outdoor and physical education through inclusive, developmentally appropriate progressions. Introduction to theoretical, philosophical and practical research dimensions of constructivist learning and teaching approaches with reference to the BC Curriculum. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 534 (3) Health Promotion and Education
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: EDCP_V 537 (3) Foundations of Home Economics Education
Description: A review and critical analysis of the history and philosophy of school home economics programs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 538 (3) Theory and Research in Environmental Education
Description: Research literature and theoretical issues in environmental education. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 539 (3) Narrativity, Ecopedagogy and Indigeneity
Description: Through seminars, course readings, and experiential learning, the power of narrative is explored as it intersects with ecological and Indigenous knowings and practices toward a more multi-storied, just, and ecologically sustainable world. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 541 (3) Problems in Historical Understanding
Description: Recent controversies in North American historical literature and implications for school curriculum in the light of research on teaching and learning history. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 542 (3) Theorizing Pedagogy
Description: Pedagogy as construed by teacher-researchers, curriculum thinkers, indigenous scholars, educational philosophers, and cultural theorists. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 544 (3) Mathematics and Science Teaching and Learning with Technologies
Description: Theoretical underpinnings and pedagogical, social and economic implications of 21st century technology-enhanced mathematics and science education. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 545 (3) Educational Programming in Museums
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 546 (3) Indigenous Visual Expression as Pedagogy
Description: Pedagogical implications of Indigenous art making and visual expression both for Indigenous peoples and for non-Indigenous viewers and consumers through the lenses of misrepresentation, self-representation, and auto-pedagogical potential and practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 550 (3) Mathematics Education: Origins and Issues
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 551 (3) Mathematics Education: Current Issues
Description: An advanced course in curriculum and pedagogy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 552 (3) Mathematics Education: Early Years
Description: Recent theories and research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 553 (3) Mathematics Education: Beyond the Early Years
Description: Recent theories and research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 555 (3) Critical Analysis of Curriculum in Science Education
Description: Current ideas about science curriculum, the nature of science, and its implications for scientific literacy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 556 (3) Theory and Research in the Social Context of School Science
Description: Historical and current social, political and economic influences on science curriculum and science teaching. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 557 (3) Issues in the Teaching and Learning of the Sciences
Description: Conceptual and practical issues associated with contemporary approaches. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 558 (3) Science Learning in Informal Environments
Description: Theoretical perspectives and current research on science learning in contexts other than formal science classes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: EDCP_V 559 (3) Research in the Teaching and Learning of the Sciences
Description: Current models and methods of inquiry in science education. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Such areas include ew media, installation and performance art, and music performance. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. Title: DANI_V 100 (3) Elementary Danish I
Description: Students with native or near-native proficiency in a Scandinavian language (e.g. Danish, Norwegian, Swedish) cannot participate in the elementary Danish courses (DANI 100 and DANI 110), but are welcome to join the intermediate courses (DANI 200 and DANI 210).
Title: DANI_V 110 (3) Elementary Danish II
Description: Students with native or near-native proficiency in a Scandinavian language (e.g. Danish, Norwegian, Swedish) cannot participate in the elementary Danish courses (DANI 100 and DANI 110), but are welcome to join the intermediate courses (DANI 200 and DANI 210).
Title: DANI_V 200 (3) Intermediate Danish I

Title: DANI_V 210 (3) Intermediate Danish II
Description: 
Title: DSCI_V 100 (3) Introduction to Data Science
Description: Use of data science tools to summarize, visualize, and analyze data. Sensible workflows and clear interpretations are emphasized. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: MATH 12
Title: DSCI_V 310 (3) Reproducible and Trustworthy Workflows for Data Science
Description: Data science methods to automate the running and testing of code and analytic reports, manage data analysis software dependencies, package and deploy software for data analysis, and collaborate with others using version control. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: DSCI 100 and either (a) one of CPSC 203, CPSC 210, CPEN 221 or (b) one of MATH 210, ECON 323 and one of CPSC 107, CPSC 110.
Title: DSCI_V 320 (3) Visualization for Data Science
Description: Analysis, design, and implementation of static and interactive visual representations; visualization literacy; data communication; exploratory Data Analysis; application of theoretical principles to visualization development. [3-1.5-0] Prerequisite: STAT 201 and one of CPSC 203, CPSC 210, CPEN 221.
Title: DSCI_V 430 (3) Fairness, Accountability, Transparency and Ethics (FATE) in Data Science
Description: Ethical application of data science and machine learning algorithms. Application of ethical theories in real-world case studies. Data ownership, collection, and validity. Algorithm auditing, fairness and transparency. Reducing unfairness in algorithms. Deployment of predictive models and dissemination of results. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of CPSC 330, CPSC 340, STAT 301, STAT 406.
Title: DSCI_V 511 (1) Programming for Data Science
Description: Pseudo-code. Program design and structure. Flow control. Iteration. Lists (arrays). Functions. File I/O. Classes, objects, methods, and libraries. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 512 (1) Algorithms and Data Structures
Description: Basic algorithms. Recursion. Data structures including linked lists, queues, stacks, trees, graphs, and hash tables. Searching and sorting. Introduction to complexity including Big-O notation, efficiency, and scalability. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 511, DSCI 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 513 (1) Databases and Data Retrieval
Description: Relational schemas. SQL queries. Database programming using embedded SQL. XML and XQuery. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 521 (1) Computing Platforms for Data Science
Description: Introduction to software, shells, tools, and file systems for use in the Data Science program. Installation, configuration, and use of statistical and programming software including Integrated Development Environments (IDEs). Problem resolution skills. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 522 (1) Data Science Workflows
Description: Interactive and non-interactive data analysis. Scripting. Dynamic reporting. Reproducibility. Project and file management. Version control. Automated workflows. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 511, DSCI 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 523 (1) Programming for Data Manipulation
Description: Program design and data manipulation using industry-standard software tools designed for statistical work. Organizing, filtering, sorting, grouping, reformatting, converting, and cleaning data to prepare it for further analysis. Corequisite: All of DSCI 511, DSCI 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 524 (1) Collaborative Software Development
Description: Software life cycle. Unit testing. Continuous integration. Submission to a relevant repository for distribution. Packaging for installation and use by others. Software licenses. Classes and abstraction. Prerequisite: DSCI 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 525 (1) Web and Cloud Computing
Description: Networks and the Internet, scraping data, APIs, cloud computing, Web services for scalable computing, Web hosting, Web publication platforms, introduction to parallel computing. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 522, DSCI 523. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 531 (1) Data Visualization I
Description: Descriptive plots using statistical and programming software. Basics, mechanics, and principles of data visualization. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 511, DSCI 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 532 (1) Data Visualization II
Description: Interactive visualization, design choices, dynamic change over time, multiple views, data reduction, dealing with complexity. Prerequisite: DSCI 531. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 541 (1) Privacy, Ethics, and Security
Description: Privacy and data. Ethics boards, legal issues, licensing. Physical and logical data security, social engineering. Encryption, data anonymization, privacy-preserving techniques. Case studies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 542 (1) Communication and Argumentation
Description: Claims, reasons, and evidence. Strengths and weaknesses of models. Effective oral and written presentation of scientific results, including interpretation of data and recognition of assumptions, bias, validity, and reliability. Citations, references, and peer-review. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 551 (1) Descriptive Statistics and Probability for Data Science
Description: Descriptive statistics including measures of location and spread. Random variables, distributions, and parameters. Categorical variables. Uncertainty. Missing data. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 552 (1) Statistical Inference and Computation I
Description: Random variables, parameters, observed data, statistics (distinctions and connections). Estimation: point and interval. Two-group comparisons, frequentist version. Simulation-based approaches. Prerequisite: DSCI 551. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 553 (1) Statistical Inference and Computation II
Description: Multiple hypothesis testing, false discovery rate. Two-group comparisons, Bayesian paradigm. Prerequisite: DSCI 552. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 554 (1) Experimentation and Causal Inference
Description: Randomization. A/B testing. Blocked designs. Orthogonality. Batch effects, confounding. Causality. Contemporary examples. Simulations. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 553, DSCI 561. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 561 (1) Regression I
Description: Linear models: continuous response; one or more categorical covariates and/or one or more continuous covariates. Prerequisite: DSCI 552. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 562 (1) Regression II
Description: Non-parametric regression and smoothing. Data-driven parameter selection. Robust regression. Mixed effects. Prerequisite: DSCI 561. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 563 (1) Unsupervised Learning
Description: Unsupervised learning. K-means/medoids. Model-based clustering. Expectation-maximization algorithm. Hierarchical clustering. Dimension reduction. Matrix decomposition. Heatmaps, contour plots, dendograms. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 511, DSCI 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 571 (1) Supervised Learning I
Description: Decision trees. k-th nearest neighbour classifiers. Naive Bayes classifiers. Logistic regression. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 511, DSCI 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 572 (1) Supervised Learning II
Description: Support Vector Machines. Random Forests. Ensemble Classifiers. Graphical models. Prerequisite: DSCI 571. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 573 (1) Feature and Model Selection
Description: Performance of a classification model. Generalization error, overfitting of training data. Shrinkage, feature selection, Akaike Information Criterion, Bayesian Information Criterion. k-fold cross validation. Bootstrapping. Receiver Operating Characteristic curve. Elastic nets, regularization. Prerequisite: DSCI 571. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 574 (1) Spatial and Temporal Models
Description: Time series. State space and change point detection. Hidden Markov Models. Gaussian processes. Prerequisite: DSCI 572. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 575 (1) Advanced Machine Learning
Description: Neural networks trained with backpropagation. Deep learning. Overfitting and underfitting. Active data acquisition. Hyperparameter optimization. Prerequisite: DSCI 572. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DSCI_V 591 (6) Capstone Project
Description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in leading complex multidisciplinary projects relevant to data science. Prerequisite: All of DSCI 513, DSCI 524, DSCI 525, DSCI 532, DSCI 541, DSCI 542, DSCI 554, DSCI 563, DSCI 573, DSCI 574, DSCI 575. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DHYG_V 106 (3) Basics of Oral Microbiology
Description: Basic principles in the study of microorganisms and their relation to human health for dental hygiene students.
Title: DHYG_V 108 (3) Oral Health Sciences I
Description: An introduction to normal, healthy facial, oral, and dental structures; oral health records, and charting terminology and symbols.
Title: DHYG_V 110 (6) Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice I
Description: An introduction to the Dental Hygiene profession, practice roles, the process of care model, ethical practice, and dental public health.
Title: DHYG_V 206 (3) Head & Neck Anatomy
Description: Prerequisite: All of BIOL 153, DHYG 108.
Title: DHYG_V 208 (12) Oral Health Sciences II
Description: An introduction to desease-related concepts during the study of dental materials, general pathology, plaque biofilm, nutrition, radiology, periodontology, and oral pathology. Prerequisite: DHYG 108. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DHYG_V 210 (18) Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice II
Description: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice in clinical and community-based settings. Prerequisite: DHYG 110. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DHYG_V 308 (6) Oral Health Sciences III
Description: An introduction to concepts and principles of pharmacology and local anesthesia, and further study of oral medicine, oral pathology, and radiology. Prerequisite: DHYG 208.
Title: DHYG_V 310 (18) Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice III
Description: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice with emphasis on diverse clients with oral health care needs. Prerequisite: DHYG 210. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DHYG_V 325 (3) Applied Pharmacology
Description: Applied pharmacology concepts and principles for the dental health professional.
Title: DHYG_V 400 (3-6) Policy Analysis and Change
Description: Critical reviews of oral health care delivery, oral disease processes and dental hygiene. [3-0-0]
Title: DHYG_V 401 (6) Oral Epidemiology
Description: Basic epidemiological and statistical concepts and tests relevant to evidence-based oral health practices.
Title: DHYG_V 402 (6) Dental Hygiene Practice I
Description: Dental hygiene concepts, processes, and skills for individuals and communities. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]
Title: DHYG_V 404 (6) Dental Hygiene Practice II
Description: Advanced dental hygiene concepts, processes and skills in community health, educational or institutional settings.
Title: DHYG_V 405 (3) Oral Microbiology and Immunology
Description: Microbiology and immunological concepts relevant for dental hygiene practice.
Title: DHYG_V 406 (6) Guided Study in Dental Hygiene
Description: Conduct an in-depth investigation of a health promotion issue. Prerequisite: All of DHYG 400, DHYG 401, DHYG 461. And Faculty approval.
Title: DHYG_V 410 (18) Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice IV
Description: Critical analysis of dental hygiene theory and practice related to diverse clients with complex oral health care needs. Prerequisite: DHYG 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DHYG_V 412 (6) Oral Health Care Trends & Topics
Description: Critical analysis of health care trends and oral health care delivery with emphasis on underserved diverse populations. Prerequisite: Pre or Corequisite: DHYG 462
Title: DHYG_V 433 (3) Assessment and Treatment Planning for Advanced Periodontal Diseases
Description: Available in online distance education format only.
Title: DHYG_V 435 (3) Oral Medicine and Pathology
Description: Pathobiology of oral diseases. Available in online distance education format only.
Title: DHYG_V 461 (3) Critical Appraisal and Professional Writing in Quantitative Research
Description: Corequisite: DHYG 401.
Title: DHYG_V 462 (3) Critical Appraisal and Professional Writing in Qualitative Research
Description: Prerequisite: DHYG 461. Corequisite: DHYG 401.
Title: DHYG_V 480 (3) Social Entrepreneurship in Oral Health Care
Description: Contemporary topics in social entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship in the context of oral health services and the delivery of care. Transformative leadership and innovation within the dynamic landscape of the Canadian healthcare system. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DENT_V 407 (6) Special Oral Care in the Community
Description: Provision of special oral health services in community settings. Prerequisite: All of DHYG 405, DHYG 435. Prerequisites may be waived for non-program dental hygienists and others.
Title: DENT_V 410 (35) Dentistry I: Foundations of Clinical Dentistry
Description: Fundamentals of human biology, body systems, diseases, and supporting basic oral health sciences. Learning in small groups, classroom, laboratory, and clinical settings utilizing technology. Professionalism, ethics, interprofessional education and the social contract, communication skills, and critical evaluation of the literature. Begin to apply foundation knowledge and skills to patient assessment and care. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DENT_V 420 (38) Dentistry II: Basic Clinical Dentistry
Description: Continued exposure to body systems and the supporting biomedical sciences with applications in dental clinical sciences, integrated into small group learning, classroom, laboratory, and community settings utilizing technology; continued engagement in professionalism, ethics and communication skills. Prerequisite: DENT 410. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DENT_V 430 (36) Dentistry III: Intermediate Clinical Dentistry
Description: A multi-disciplinary course integrating didactic, simulation, clinical, and community service learning. Students function as team members in clinical group practices with individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships. Prerequisite: DENT420
Title: DENT_V 440 (32) Dentistry IV: Complex Clinical Dentistry
Description: A continuing integrated, multi-disciplinary course with ongoing participation in clinical group practices and individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships and community service learning. Prerequisite: DENT430 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: DENT_V 578 (6) Endodontic Literature Review I
Description: Dental anatomy, morphology, endodontic instruments, diagnosis and differential diagnosis, etiology and pathogenesis of endodontic infections, and strategies of infection control. [2-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DENT_V 584 (6) Endodontic Literature Review II
Description: Endodontic epidemiology, materials, prognosis of treatment, geriatric endodontics, complications, treatment resistant infections, and endo-perio lesions. [2-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: DES_V 101 (1) Introductory Workshop
Description: Week long orientation to the School community, the City and the study of design one week prior to the start of Winter Session Term 1. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 101 or DES 101. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 110 (3) Measured Architectural Drawing
Description: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing techniques. Open to all UBC students regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 110 or DES 110.
Title: DES_V 130 (3) Design, Culture and Ecology
Description: Survey of the visual, cultural, ecological and spatial literacies in architectural and urban design.
Title: DES_V 200 (3) Design Thinking
Description: Design thinking through the analysis of architecture, landscape architecture and urban design and through hands-on design projects. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will granted for only one of ENDS 231 or DES 200. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 201 (6) Design Studio I - Context and Site
Description: Design within the context of various analytical lenses including ecological, climatic, social, political, cultural and historical influences. Prerequisite: One of DES 110, VISA 180. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 202 (6) Design Studio II - Form
Description: Essential processes and methods for thinking in three-dimensional spatial terms. Prerequisite: A score of 60% or higher in DES 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 211 (3) Design Media I
Description: Techniques in architectural drawing, two-dimensional representation, three-dimensional representation and general visual literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 320, ARCH 515 or DES 211. Prerequisite: One of DES 110, VISA 180. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 212 (3) Design Media II
Description: Advanced techniques in architectural representation and discourse in digital representation and digital making. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 437, ARCH 517 or DES 212. Prerequisite: DES 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 220 (3) Architecture and Urbanism in Context: Vancouver and its Region
Description: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region. Open enrolment course. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 220 or DES 220.
Title: DES_V 230 (3) Sustainability by Design
Description: Interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 221 or DES 230. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 231 (3) Site Analysis and Planning
Description: Analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Credit will be given for only one of DES 231, LARC 440, or LARC 540. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 232 (3) Material Culture
Description: An investigation of building materials and associated design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 232 or ARCH 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 301 (9) Design Studio III - Building Scale Synthesis
Description: Design at the architectural scale through the medium of program and site. Prerequisite: A score of 60% or higher in DES 202. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 302 (9) Design Studio IV - Vancouver
Description: Vancouver as a laboratory for design at the architectural and urban scale with a focused view into how design is implicated in the social, political, and environmental transformation of the city. Prerequisite: A score of 60% or higher in DES 301. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 320 (3) History of the Design of the Built Environment
Description: A broad historical introduction to architectural and landscape architectural design within the context of politics, economics and culture. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 321 (3-9) Topics in Architectural History I (Pre-1900)
Description: History of architecture in the pre-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes that have influenced architecture and related fields. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 321, ARCH 404 or ARCH 504. Prerequisite: DES 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 322 (3-9) Topics in Architectural History II (1900-Present)
Description: History of architecture in the post-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes which have influenced architecture and related fields. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 322, ARCH 405 or ARCH 505. Prerequisite: DES 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 323 (3) Histories in Landscape Architecture
Description: Landscapes from medieval times to the present studied synchronically across design elements as well as chronologically with the development of several key historical concepts. Prerequisite: DES 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 330 (3) Structural Systems and Supports
Description: Basic structural systems in the built world including wood, steel, concrete, composite systems and essential structural logics of soil retention systems and drainage. Prerequisite: All of DES 231, DES 232. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 341 (3) Co-operative Education Work Term I
Description: Supervised, technical work- integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to undergraduate students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program. Prerequisite: APSC 107. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 350 (3) Design Build
Description: Direct hands-on confrontation with the realities of design and construction, engaging in both conventional and unconventional building processes. Prerequisite: DES 302.
Title: DES_V 401 (9) Design Studio V - Urban Systems Scale Synthesis
Description: Relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure and ecological systems. Prerequisite: A score of 60% or higher in DES 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 402 (9) Design Studio VI - Away
Description: A design project engaged with an international context and site. Emphasis placed on mapping, interpretation of the international context as well as methods of construction, notions of program, and policies, regulations and codes that relate to the site. Prerequisite: A score of 60% or higher in DES 401. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 403 (9) Senior Design Project
Description: Final design project in the Honours Option with an independently conceived methodology allowing a student the opportunity to pursue his/her own set of interests and concerns. Prerequisite: A sessional average of 80% or better in each of years 2 and 3 and a grade of 80% or better in each of DES 201, 202, 301, 302 and DES 401. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 421 (3) Design Theory
Description: Introduction to a broad range of theories in architecture and design as they relate to the built environment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 422 (3) Urbanism by Design
Description: A history of the planning, landscape architecture and urban design of cities, and of how ideas have influenced the design of the city. Prerequisite: One of DES 321, DES 322, DES 323. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 430 (3) Environment, Urban Form, and Infrastructure
Description: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and infrastructure of livability of cities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 442 (3) Co-operative Education Work Term II
Description: Supervised, technical work- integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to undergraduate students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program. Prerequisite: DES 341. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 443 (3) Co-operative Education Work Term III
Description: Supervised, technical work- integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to undergraduate students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program. Prerequisite: DES 442. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 444 (3) Co-operative Education Work Term IV
Description: Supervised, technical work- integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to undergraduate students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program. Prerequisite: DES 443. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 445 (3) Entrepreneurship and Ethics in Design
Description: Core business skills, building on students' design capabilities to pursue ethical and sustainable design-based business goals. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 450 (1-9) Special Topics
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DES_V 562 (3) Research Seminar
Description: Processes, procedures, ethics and quality expectations of advanced research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Description: Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: DMED_V 500 (3) Foundations of Digital Entertainment
Description: Business, technological, social, and ethical issues of digital entertainment introduced and framed though historical exploration and critical analysis of economics, technical innovations, social demands, and ethical constraints involved. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 501 (3) Visual Story
Description: The many facets of storytelling are explored, with an emphasis on development of narrative using shape, colour, line, texture, and composition, as well as text and sound. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 502 (3) Improvising Story and Character
Description: Techniques of improvisational acting are used to develop collaborative and creative skills in building dramatic themes, narratives, and characters. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 503 (3) Foundations of Game Design
Description: Analysis of games as rules, games as play, and games as culture. Students make both physical and electronic games as part of this course. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 510 (3) Financing and Distribution of Digital Entertainment
Description: Methods of financing and distributing video games, mobile content, theatrical feature films, television projects, and series. Drafting and negotiating contracts and intellectual property law related to digital entertainment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 520 (6) Projects I: Building Virtual Worlds
Description: Student teams design and implement an artifact in a virtual environment. Management and business aspects of team-based creation are studied. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 521 (12) Projects II
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 522 (12) Projects III
Description: Pre- or Co-requisite: DMED 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 523 (12) Projects IV
Description: Pre- or Co-requisite: DMED 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 530 (6) Internship
Description: Full-time work experience related to digital media or entertainment technology, outside the university. Students learn effective communication, collaboration, project management, and team cooperation. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: DMED_V 540 (3) Special Projects in Digital Media I

Title: MEDD_V 411 (17) Foundations of Medical Practice I
Description: Integrating foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Organized on the basis of clinical presentations. Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 412 (15) Foundations of Medical Practice II
Description: Increasingly complex clinical presentations through integration of foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Developmental, case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 419 (8) Foundations of Scholarship and Flexible Enhanced Learning I
Description: Various medically-related learning experiences and scholarly activities. Emphasizes social accountability, introduces scholarly methods, and fosters innovation, creativity, and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 421 (15) Foundations of Medical Practice III
Description: Increasingly complex clinical presentations integrating foundational sciences and clinical practice themes. Developmental, case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 422 (15) Transition into Clinical Education
Description: Prepares students to transition from classroom-based to clinical learning environments. Increasingly complex clinical presentations integrating foundational sciences and clinical practice themes. Prepares students for clinical practice in Year 3 Clerkship. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 429 (6) Flexible Enhanced Learning II
Description: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation, creativity, and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 431 (48) Clerkship
Description: Core experiences across the breadth of medicine through clinical and academic learning opportunities in ambulatory, hospital-based, and rural/remote settings. Interactions with patients under supervision. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 440 (24) Senior Elective
Description: Senior Elective encompasses 6 months of Year 4 of the MD undergraduate program. Students will choose from available electives between 2 and 4 weeks in duration and participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with those electives. Pass/fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 448 (9) Transition into Postgraduate Education and Practice
Description: Enables students to effectively transition from medical school to residency and medical practice. Complex clinical presentations that integrate foundational sciences and practice themes. Prepares students for practice as residents and physicians. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 449 (4) Flexible Enhanced Learning III
Description: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, lifelong learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 451 (0) Clinical Skills IV
Description: Final examination for fourth year encompassing all clinical subjects. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MEDD_V 499 (4-8) Clinical Electives
Description: Summer clinical experience for UBC medical graduates who did not attain a residency position. Prerequisite: Students must have a UBC MD degree and have fully completed applications to residency positions for the first iteration of the postgraduate match in their Year 4 (submission of a Rank Order List to the Canadian Residency Matching Service, CaRMS). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: ECED_V 415 (3) Supporting Learning in The Primary Years.

Title: ECED_V 416 (3) Kindergarten Curriculum
