Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HGSE_V 310 (3) First Nations and Canada: (Re)writing History
Description: A survey of the history of Indigenous peoples in relation to the Canadian colonial state contrasting the Indigenous historical experience with conventional accounts of Canadian history.
Title: HGSE_V 311 (3) Law and Governance: Indigenous and European Traditions
Description: Background on sources of Aboriginal and Canadian law; detail on section 35 of the Constitution Act; a review of relevant Canadian case law; insight on the importance of international law; and literature on governance.
Title: HGSE_V 312 (3) Perspectives on Reconciliation
Description: Notions of reconciliation and restitution that have emerged in Canada across space and time; key principles, discourses, legal and Constitutional mechanisms, actions and actors.
Title: HGSE_V 313 (3) Reconciliation and Resource Management
Description: Relationships and reconciliation processes between Indigenous peoples and other governments in the context of land and sea governance.
Title: HGSE_V 314 (3) Reconciliation and Communities
Description: In-depth exploration of the communities of Haida Gwaii through community-based experiences and community service learning.
Title: HGSE_V 320 (1-12) Special Topics on Ecology and Society
Description: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by instructors teaching with the Haida Gwaii Institute. The course is expected to be of a specialized nature and be at a level appropriate for upper level students.
Title: HGSE_V 330 (3) Social Ecological Change: An Introduction to Systems Thinking and Resilience
Description: Conceptual tools of systems thinking, complexity and trans-systemics to aid understanding the dynamics of socialecological transformation and social innovation. These tools will be presented and complemented by experiences on Haida Gwaii that will foster an understanding of social change and system transformation for reconciliation. Complex problems. Prerequisite: Third-year Standing.
Title: HGSE_V 331 (3) Environmental Assessment in Cross-Cultural and Indigenous Contexts
Description: An introduction to the field and practice of environmental assessment (EA) in Canada with specific reference to EA processes in cross-cultural and Indigenous contexts. Includes cases specific to Haida Gwaii and engagement with local, community educators from Haida Gwaii. Prerequisite: Third-year Standing.
Title: HGSE_V 332 (3) Plant Ecology and Diversity
Description: Examination of global vegetation, incorporating distribution, abundance, interactions between plants and other organisms, and the role of plants in different environments. Concepts will be addressed the ecosystems of the coastal temperate rainforest in general, and of Haida Gwaii in particular. Prerequisite: Third-year Standing.
Title: HGSE_V 333 (3) Indigenous Plant Knowledge: Ethnoecology and Ethnobotany
Description: Ethnoecology and ethnobotany within the context of Haida culture and language and the ecosystems of Haida Gwaii, along with examples from other Indigenous communities in British Columbia and the Yukon. Prerequisite: Third-year Standing.
Title: HGSE_V 350 (3) Case Studies in Haida Gwaii
Description: Integration of concepts of history, politics, First Nations, rural development, and forest ecology in natural resources management in Haida Gwaii. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
Title: HGSE_V 351 (3) History and Politics of Resource Management
Description: Historical examination of resource management in Canada and conflicts arising therefrom, with emphasis on forests.
Title: HGSE_V 352 (3) Indigenous Governance and Land Stewardship
Description: The political, economic, and legal environment of Aboriginal-Canadian relations and its influence on resource use and management; review of historic relationships, emerging case law, and new reconciliation frameworks.
Title: HGSE_V 353 (3) Rainforest Ecology and Management
Description: Ecology of the temperate rainforests of Haida Gwaii. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
Title: HGSE_V 354 (3) Diversifying Resource-Dependent Communities
Description: Examination of the forces that restructure local economies, both historically and contemporarily; link between rural economic development and the legacy of resource development in Aboriginal communities across British Columbia. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
Title: HGSE_V 355 (3) Applied Ecology of Coastal Terrestrial Ecosystems
Description: Processes that shape coastal terrestrial ecosystems through time and applications to current ecological reality. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
Title: HGSE_V 356 (3) Biophysical Dynamics of the Marine-Terrestrial Interface
Description: Nutrient cycling between the marine environment and coastal forest ecosystems; how the physical characteristics of this interface affect inputs; which species play a pivotal role in driving interactions. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
Title: HGSE_V 357 (3) Ecology and Management of Island Wildlife
Description: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or HGSE 357. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
Title: HGSE_V 358 (3) Systems Thinking for Resource Management
Description: Introduction to systems thinking and resilience to understand dynamics of social change and innovation; use of case studies to demonstrate applications of different types of ecological knowledge, including traditional knowledge and experiential knowledge. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
Title: HGSE_V 359 (3) Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
Description: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester. Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
Title: HGSE_V 360 (3) Ocean People, Culture and Tradition
Description: The relationship between the culture of the Haida people and their marine environment; and traditional and modern approaches to management of marine resources.
Title: HGSE_V 361 (3) Fisheries Co-Management of the North Pacific Coast
Description: Concepts of fisheries co-management with a focus on the North Pacific Coast; examples of other comanagement structures regionally and internationally.
Title: HGSE_V 362 (3) Marine Protected Areas and Marine Spatial Planning
Description: Key concepts in MSP and key elements inherent in MPA and MPA network design, governance, implementation, management, compliance and monitoring.
Title: HGSE_V 363 (3) Applications in Marine Conservation
Description: Exposure to field settings and research techniques in local marine environments.
Title: HGSE_V 364 (3) Haida Gwaii Marine Conservation Seminar
Description: Key marine conservation issues, pairing broad topics with examples on Haida Gwaii to bring theory into practice.
Title: HGSE_V 370 (3) Introduction to Resilience Theory in Community
Description: Theory of social-ecological resilience as applied to cross-cultural community settings, using case studies from communities on Haida Gwaii and other exceptional cases of community resilience.
Title: HGSE_V 371 (3) Re-Storying History: Indigenous Perspective
Description: Exploration of the diversity of Indigenous peoples of British Columbia and Canada and their unique histories, beginning with origin stories and oral histories and moving on to the histories and relationships that Indigenous groups have with the federal, provincial and territorial governments.
Title: HGSE_V 372 (3) Language and Cultural Continuity
Description: An exploration of language as a means of looking at culture, and cultural continuity. Using Xaad Kilthe Haida language as a framing device, students will explore the integral connections between language, culture, history, land, health and resilience.
Title: HGSE_V 373 (3) Community Planning and Development for Resilience
Description: An examination of the challenges and opportunities of developing and diversifying resilient resource dependent cross-cultural, rural communities using Haida Gwaii's comprehensive community planning as a case study.
Title: HGSE_V 374 (3) Community Resilience Seminar
Description: The application of theory, concepts, stories, and histories of community resilience through focused readings, group discussions and engagement with local speakers to provide the opportunity to engage deeply and work at the theory-practice interface.
Title: HGSE_V 380 (3) Systems Thinking and Social-Ecological Change
Description: Theories of systems change, including complex systems thinking, resilience/transformation, transition management and other social science-based change theories. Corequisite: All of HGSE 382, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.
Title: HGSE_V 381 (3) Ecological Economics
Description: Underlying philosophy and principles of ecological economics, including the cascading effects of change, unintended consequences of change, and why it might be difficult to separate our ecological goals from our political realities.
Title: HGSE_V 382 (3) Political and Legal Aspects of Systems Change
Description: An examination of the emergence of Aboriginal Law in Canada, with a focus on the development of Aboriginal law as an innovation in shaping new contexts for Federal-, Provincial- and Corporate-Indigenous relations and its implications for systems transformation. Corequisite: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 383, HGSE 384.
Title: HGSE_V 383 (3) Social Innovation and Entrepreneurship
Description: An examination of the relationships between culture, ingenuity, creativity, entrepreneurship and innovation required to understand and foster systems change through Indigenous and cross-cultural examples. Corequisite: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 384.
Title: HGSE_V 384 (3) Case Studies in Social-Ecological Change
Description: An exploration of complex issues of social-ecological change in the current social-economic-political context of reconciliation initiatives and Indigenous governance, highlighting the Haida worldview and Haida ways of knowing and being with western understandings of social-ecological systems. Corequisite: All of HGSE 380, HGSE 382, HGSE 383.
Title: HGSE_V 394 (3) Marine Conservation in British Columbia
Description: Perspectives and methodologies applied to the conservation of marine environments in British Columbia.
Title: HESO_V 400 (3-6) Sociocultural Determinants of Health
Description: Methods for analyzing population health data and medical research reporting.
Title: HESO_V 449 (3-6) Topics in Health and Society
Description: 
Title: HEBR_V 101 (3) Beginning Biblical Hebrew I
Description: Biblical Hebrew, with an introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of simple biblical texts in the original.
Title: HEBR_V 102 (3) Beginning Biblical Hebrew II
Description: Biblical Hebrew, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of biblical texts in the original. Prerequisite: HEBR 101.
Title: HEBR_V 205 (3) Beginning Biblical Hebrew II
Description: Biblical Hebrew, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of biblical texts in the original. Credit will be granted for only one of HEBR 102 or HEBR 205. Prerequisite: HEBR 101. Equivalency: HEBR 102
Title: HEBR_V 301 (3) Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I
Description: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to enrich vocabulary and grammar and enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts. Credit will be granted for only one of HEBR 201 or HEBR 301. Prerequisite: One of HEBR 102, HEBR 205. Equivalency: HEBR 201
Title: HEBR_V 302 (3) Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II
Description: Biblical Hebrew. Devised to further enrich vocabulary and grammar and to enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of biblical texts. Credit will be granted for only one of HEBR 202 or HEBR 302. Prerequisite: One of HEBR 201, HEBR 301. Equivalency: HEBR 202
Title: HEBR_V 479 (3-12) Supervised Study in Classical Hebrew
Description: Prerequisite: One of HEBR 202, HEBR 302. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HEBR_V 509 (3-12) Advanced Readings in Classical Hebrew
Description: Credit will not be given for both HEBR 479 and HEBR 509. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HPB_V 501 (3) Green Building Contemporary Practice
Description: Enhanced building environmental performance and the integration of green building principles, strategies and technologies. Equivalency: ARCH574 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HPB_V 502 (3) Regenerative Development
Description: The relationship between human and natural systems in the context of regenerative design. Provides an understanding of how regenerative approaches differ from green design and how they can offer new insights and directions for design. Equivalency: ARCH575 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HPB_V 503 (3) Whole Building Energy Modelling and Simulation
Description: Modelling energy in a high performance building. Introduction to indoor space requirements. Heat and mass transfer through building envelopes. Climate. Fenestration, daylighting, solar energy. Introduction to major energy models. Modelling project. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HPB_V 504 (3) Building Energy Systems Design
Description: Designing the energy system for a high performance building. Heating, cooling and ventilation load estimation. Heating and cooling using solar, electrical and chemical energy. Air, water, and refrigerant distribution systems. Energy storage. System design project. Design performance assessment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HPB_V 505 (3) Capstone: Greening Existing Buildings
Description: Students will analyze the performance and design data of an existing building and propose design changes that will improve performance, considering the real priorities of the client, a building owner or operator. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HPB_V 506 (3) Capstone: New Building Energy Systems Design
Description: Students will take a building under design and work with the designers towards a high performance energy system. The project will be a proposed high performance building with a client, a design team, and energy performance objectives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HINU_V 100 (3) Introductory Hindi-Urdu I
Description: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100 or 102.
Title: HINU_V 101 (3) Introductory Hindi-Urdu II
Description: Continuation of HINU 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 101 or 102. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 100.
Title: HINU_V 102 (6) Introductory Hindi-Urdu
Description: Spoken and written Hindi and Urdu. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.
Title: HINU_V 200 (6) Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
Description: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 201/202 or HINU 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of HINU 101, HINU 102.
Title: HINU_V 201 (3) Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I
Description: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 201. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 101.
Title: HINU_V 202 (3) Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II
Description: Continuation of HINU 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 202. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 201.
Title: HINU_V 205 (1) Introduction to the Devanagari Script
Description: The writing system of Hindi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as HINU 200.
Title: HINU_V 300 (6) Advanced Hindi-Urdu
Description: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301/302 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of HINU 200, HINU 202.
Title: HINU_V 301 (3) Advanced Hindi-Urdu I
Description: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 202.
Title: HINU_V 302 (3) Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
Description: Continuation of HINU 301. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 302 or HINU 300. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 301.
Title: HINU_V 305 (2) Introduction to the Perso-Arabic (Urdu) Script
Description: The writing system of Urdu for those with some background in the spoken language. Corequisite: One of HINU 300, HINU 400.
Title: HINU_V 400 (6) Introduction to Hindi and Urdu Literature
Description: Readings of various literary genres in Hindi, Urdu and their medieval equivalents. Modern fiction from India and Pakistan; the Urdu ghazal; medieval Hindi bhakti poetry; readings from the Adi Granth of the Sikhs Hindi film. Discussion in Hindi-Urdu of all materials. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 300.
Title: HINU_V 450 (3) Hindi Film
Description: Regional, religious, and historical dialects of Hindi and Urdu as represented in films. Recommended pre-requisite: HINU 200 or fluency in Hindi.
Title: HIST_V 100 (3) What is History?
Description: The discipline of history through the study of questions, sources, methods, and controversies. Includes case studies of key turning points in world history to examine what historians do and why it matters.
Title: HIST_V 101 (6) Global History to 1500 CE
Description: Introduction to premodern human societies of Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas and cultural, political, social, economic, and religious exchanges from a global history perspective and introduction to historical practices.
Title: HIST_V 102 (6) World History from 1500 to the Twentieth Century
Description: The civilizations of Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas, with emphasis on the political, economic, ecological and cultural links among them, and the impact of oceanic contact, imperialism, warfare, migration, and globalization.
Title: HIST_V 103 (6) World History Since 1900
Description: International relations; changes in the nation-state system; the emergence and impact of major political ideologies; genocide; decolonization; the globalization of trade; and the dynamics of economic, social, cultural, and environmental change in a global context.
Title: HIST_V 104 (3) Topics in World History
Description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.
Title: HIST_V 105 (3) Contemporary Global Issues in Historical Perspective
Description: Places issues and problems of current relevance such as disease, terrorism, drugs, or ethnic conflict in historical perspective. Each section will explore a single theme. Check with department for course offerings.
Title: HIST_V 106 (3) Global Environmental History
Description: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization.
Title: HIST_V 107 (3) Global Indigenous Histories
Description: An introduction to the experiences of Indigenous peoples and the nature of colonialisms around the world since 1500, and an introduction to historical practices and perspectives.
Title: HIST_V 108 (3) Global History of Capitalism
Description: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization. An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era.
Title: HIST_V 109 (3) Cultural Histories of Media: From Writing to Tweeting
Description: The history of different forms of media in global perspective, with particular attention to audiovisual electronic media.
Title: HIST_V 110 (3) History of Global Migration
Description: Explores the mass migration of people in the modern world through a global perspective. Industrial and export-oriented economies in the mid-nineteenth century to contemporary issues of border regulation and refugees.
Title: HIST_V 200 (6) Asia and the World
Description: The political, economic, social, cultural, and human interactions between Asia and the world, inter-Asian relations, Asian diaspora, colonialism, war and the social consequences of conflict, decolonization, industrial growth, and developing world issues.
Title: HIST_V 201 (3) History Through Photographs
Description: The discipline of history through the study of photographs. Explores themes such as colonialism, orientalism, the mass media, representations of gender and sexuality, and protest through photographic evidence.
Title: HIST_V 202 (3-6) Gateway to the Middle Ages
Description: Problems and themes of medieval European History through the close study of the people and cultures that produced them.
Title: HIST_V 203 (3) The Global War on Terror
Description: Critically examines the origins, impacts, and legacies of the nebulous 'Global War on Terror'.
Title: HIST_V 204 (3) History Through Video Games
Description: Exploration of global histories through video games and uses of video games for research by historians.
Title: HIST_V 205 (3) Introduction to Historical Archaeology
Description: An introduction to the study of medieval and modern material culture, with special emphasis on Canada, using archaeological evidence to illustrate the principles, aims, and techniques of historical archaeology and related disciplines.
Title: HIST_V 220 (3-6) History of Europe
Description: Selected themes and historical approaches in European history; may include Europe's history of religious conflict, state formation, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, revolution, total war, globalization, genocide, or environmental change.
Title: HIST_V 235 (3) History of Canada: Moments that Matter
Description: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history. Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century.
Title: HIST_V 236 (3) Introduction to Public History in Canada: Confronting the Canadian Past
Description: An introduction to public history in Canada that explores the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, such as museums, monuments, and films, and examines questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience.
Title: HIST_V 237 (3-6) History of the United States
Description: Survey from colonial period to present examining political system, slavery, Civil War, race relations and civil rights, westward expansion, industrialization, feminism, expanding international presence, Cold War, and modern culture.
Title: HIST_V 240 (3) Health, Illness and Medicine I: From the Ancient World to the Early Modern Period
Description: History of western medicine, from the Ancient World to the Enlightenment, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health, and disease, and the development of medical institutions.
Title: HIST_V 241 (3) Health, Illness and Medicine II: The Modern World from 1700 to the Present
Description: Western medicine from 1700 to the present, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health and disease, and the development of medical institutions.
Title: HIST_V 250 (3-6) Latin American History
Description: Exploring themes of colonialism, indigenous life, national imaginaries, dictatorships and transitions to democracy through different forms of telling Latin American history. Includes epistolary writing, maps, eyewitness accounts, chronicles, actions, novels, films, built environment and city plans, testimonios, and plays.
Title: HIST_V 252 (3) Modern Caribbean History
Description: A survey of social, cultural and political history of Anglophone, Francophone and Spanish Caribbean from the Haitian Revolution to the present.
Title: HIST_V 256 (3) History of Africa
Description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 256 or HIST 256. Equivalency: AFST256
Title: HIST_V 259 (3) Science, Medicine, and Technology in the Ancient and Medieval Worlds
Description: The history of science, medicine, and technology, emphasizing networks, exchanges, and encounters in a global context.
Title: HIST_V 260 (3) Science and Society in the Contemporary World
Description: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 260 or PHIL 260. Equivalency: PHIL 260.
Title: HIST_V 270 (3-6) China in World History
Description: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 270 or ASIA 270. Equivalency: ASIA 270
Title: HIST_V 271 (3) Japan and Global History, 1550 - 1900
Description: Thematic study of comparisons and relations between Japan and the world outside (primarily Europe and China). Commercial expansion, systems of world order, social institutions, religious and ideological expression, and state organization.
Title: HIST_V 273 (3) History of India
Description: Societies, cultures, and politics of the Indian subcontinent from its ancient civilizations to the formation of the modern nation-states of South Asia.
Title: HIST_V 279 (3) Steppe Empires in World History
Description: Powerful empires that flourished over the Eurasian Steppe, from the earliest to modern times, and how regimes and cultures associated with these empires have changed the world.
Title: HIST_V 280 (3) Islamic World History
Description: The history of the Islamic world in its global dimensions from its origins to the present day through the themes of religion, law, politics, culture, and modernity.
Title: HIST_V 300 (3) Vikings: Then and Now
Description: Historical and archaeological study of Viking-Age and premodern Scandinavia and the Vikings complex legacies in contemporary cultural heritage.
Title: HIST_V 302 (6) History of the Indigenous Peoples of North America
Description: Indigenous peoples from pre-contact to the present in Canada and the U.S. Topics include colonial frontiers, disease, fur trade, government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, activism, urbanization, and identity.
Title: HIST_V 303 (6) History of the Canadian West
Description: Selected topics in the history of the Canadian West with an emphasis on the prairie west: the Indian and the fur trade, Louis Riel, prairie settlement, and western social and political protest.
Title: HIST_V 304 (3) Researching Local History from the Ground Up
Description: Sources and methods for reconstructing local history that can be used by Social Studies teachers in B.C. The aim is to develop an appreciation of the formative processes and past experiences that created one's familiar community.
Title: HIST_V 305 (3) History of British Columbia
Description: The social, political, cultural, environmental, and economic transformations that have made British Columbia. Topics include the histories of Indigenous and settler peoples, the modern state, migration, activism, and identity.
Title: HIST_V 306 (6) History of France, 1461-1715
Description: The development of absolute monarchy in France, with emphasis on change and conflict in French society; spiritual and intellectual crisis; the place of France in the emerging European state system; and opposition to the monarchy.
Title: HIST_V 307 (3) French North America to 1803
Description: Historical background for understanding the French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Quebecois, French-Canadians and Cajuns. It also deals extensively with French-Indigenous relations and introduces the student to the historiography of French North America.
Title: HIST_V 308 (3) Quebec from the End of the 18th Century to the Present
Description: Relations between the English and the Canadians prior to the Rebellions of 1837-38, the emergence of French Canadian nationalism after 1840, the impact of State formation and industrialization in Quebec, the Quiet Revolution, and the independence movement.
Title: HIST_V 309 (3) Topics in Sub-Saharan African History
Description: Examination of a major theme in the history of Sub-Saharan Africa.
Title: HIST_V 310 (3) The British Empire to 1850
Description: Rise of the British imperial system within a global context from its beginnings to 1850. Focuses on economic and social themes with emphasis on settlements in the southern hemisphere as well as the West Indies.
Title: HIST_V 311 (3) The British Empire after 1850
Description: Transformation of the British imperial system from the mid-nineteenth century to de-colonization and neo-colonialism after the second World War.
Title: HIST_V 312 (3) Southern Africa
Description: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary, emphasizing South Africa. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 312 or HIST 312. Equivalency: AFST312
Title: HIST_V 313 (3) Africa from Imperialism to Independence
Description: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 313 or HIST 313. Equivalency: AFST313
Title: HIST_V 314 (6) Early Modern Britain
Description: The social, economic, political, religious, cultural, and intellectual history of Britain between the Reformation and the Industrial Revolution, emphasizing the rise of modern industrial society.
Title: HIST_V 315 (3) Britain 1750-1850
Description: Emergence of the world's first industrial society, and the political, economic, and cultural struggles accompanying this transformation.
Title: HIST_V 317 (3) Britain, 1850-1918
Description: Britain from the Great Exhibition to the Great War: the creation of a mass electorate, the New Imperialism, the New Woman, and the ways that class, race, gender, and sexuality shaped modern Britain.
Title: HIST_V 318 (3) Early Twentieth-Century Britain
Description: British society and politics in the era of the two world wars: the liberal reforms before the Great War, war experiences, the Great Depression, and the impact of new political movements.
Title: HIST_V 319 (3) Britain, 1945 to the Present
Description: Survey of recent British history, with emphasis on de-colonization, emergence of the welfare state, new social movements and patterns of immigration, and Britain's changing relationship with Europe.
Title: HIST_V 321 (6-12) Honours Tutorial
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 322 (6-12) Honours Tutorial
Description: 
Title: HIST_V 323 (3) Empires, Wars, and Revolutions in Europe and the Americas,1763-1838
Description: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to the American, French, and Haitian Revolutions, the Latin American Wars of Independence and Canadian rebellions.
Title: HIST_V 324 (3) Inventing Canada, 1840-1896
Description: An examination of political, cultural and national developments within the British North American colonies in the second half of the nineteenth century. Credit will not be granted for both HIST 324 or 326, if 326 was taken before 2007W.
Title: HIST_V 325 (3) Canada 1896-1945: Boom, Bust and War
Description: Includes Aboriginal policy, immigration and national identity; Canada, Britain and the US; World Wars; economic modernization; the Great Depression; regionalism; political and social movements; and the creation of 'Canadian' culture. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 325 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.
Title: HIST_V 326 (3) Canada Since 1945: Affluence and Anxiety in the Atomic Age.
Description: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 326 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.
Title: HIST_V 327 (3) Colonial America: Encounter and Settlement, 1607 - 1763
Description: Encounters between European, African, and Indigenous North American peoples as well as the history of the colonies within the Atlantic world, from the late sixteenth century to the eve of the American Revolution.
Title: HIST_V 328 (3) Rebels in America: Revolution to Civil War, 1763 - 1865
Description: Issues in U.S. history from the colonial era through the Civil War, including the causes of the American Revolution; slavery; aboriginal peoples; labour, gender, and industrialization.
Title: HIST_V 329 (3) Heroes, Rebels, Villains, Folks: The People Who Shaped Canada
Description: Canadian history through the lens of individual people's lives and their social impact. Themes include race, class, gender, sexuality, indigeneity, colonialism, slavery, immigration, moral regulation, and activism.
Title: HIST_V 330 (3) History of the Global Financial Order
Description: Origins and transformation of the global financial order (18th century onward) in relation to war, state-building, international political economy, and colonialism.
Title: HIST_V 331 (3) The United States, 1865-1900: Labour, Race, Gender, and Empire
Description: The complicated political, economic and social history of the United States in the three decades following the Civil War.
Title: HIST_V 333 (3-6) Third-Year Honours Seminar
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 334 (3) African-American History, 1450 - 1850
Description: The history of African Americans from the beginnings of the African slave trade in the 15th Century through the mid-1800s and the coming of the U.S. Civil War.
Title: HIST_V 335 (3) African-American History, 1850 to the Present
Description: The history of African-Americans from the Civil War and emancipation through the present. Topics include the Jim Crow system; the Harlem Renaissance; the Civil Rights Movement; and the current economic and political status of Americans of African ancestry.
Title: HIST_V 336 (3) Imperial and Colonial Archaeology and Museums
Description: The impact of imperialism and colonialism on archaeological practice, museum collecting, and the telling of historical narratives.
Title: HIST_V 338 (3) American Modernity: The United States, 1890-1945
Description: U.S. emergence as an industrial powerhouse and, eventually, a global superpower; responses to industrial society, meaning of modern times, economic upheaval and social change, U.S.'s role as a world power, and politics of race, ethnicity, and gender.
Title: HIST_V 339 (3) The United States Since 1945: The Limits of Power
Description: American military and geo-political power during and after Cold War; wars in Korea, Vietnam, and Middle East; domestic issues including McCarthyism, social movements (blacks, women, youth, gays and lesbians, and Native Americans), consumerism, immigration, and rise of New Right.
Title: HIST_V 340 (3) Histories of the American West
Description: Frontier ideologies in relation to race, gender, class, sexuality. Place-making and historical narrative in and about the western part of the United States.
Title: HIST_V 341 (3) Medieval Jewish History
Description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.
Title: HIST_V 342 (3) Modern Jewish History
Description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, social and cultural transformations.
Title: HIST_V 344 (6) Ancient Regime France
Description: The political, social and/or cultural history of early modern France before the Revolution. Topics may include: the changing significance of the monarchy; the Enlightenment critique of the Catholic Church and religion; the 'pre-revolution'. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 344 or 406.
Title: HIST_V 346 (6) History of Modern France
Description: Political, social, and cultural history of France from the Revolution of 1789 to the present. France's journey toward democracy; particular focus on the changing nature of French culture and society.
Title: HIST_V 347 (3) Medieval and Imperial Russian History, 998 to 1800
Description: Russian politics, society, culture, and empire, beginning with the medieval period extending through the era of Peter the Great's modernization efforts and the Enlightenment.
Title: HIST_V 349 (3) Imperial Russian History, 1800 to 1917
Description: History of Russia from the time of Catherine the Great to the Russian Revolution with particular focus on social and cultural history.
Title: HIST_V 350 (6) The Soviet Union
Description: Political, social, and cultural history of the Soviet Union and post-Soviet successor states from 1900 to the present.
Title: HIST_V 351 (3-6) East Central Europe in the 19th and 20th Centuries
Description: Covers the region between Germany and Russia as well as Southeast Europe. Emphasis on comparisons with Western Europe and features that make the area significant to Europe as a whole.
Title: HIST_V 352 (3) Modern Middle Eastern History
Description: Politics, culture, society, war, and diplomacy; themes include colonialism, nationalism, and authoritarianism; emphasis on the 20th and 21st centuries.
Title: HIST_V 353 (3-6) Special Topics in Middle Eastern History
Description: An in-depth study of one major topic in the ancient and/or modern history of the Middle East. Please consult the Department webpage for current offerings.
Title: HIST_V 354 (3) The Ottoman Empire
Description: The rise and fall of the Ottoman empire; themes include Islamic law, politics, art, culture, gender relations, and the influence of religion on statecraft.
Title: HIST_V 355 (3) Nineteenth Century Germany
Description: The political, social, and cultural history of modern Germany during the long nineteenth century (1780s to the early twentieth century).
Title: HIST_V 356 (3) Twentieth-Century Germany
Description: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century.
Title: HIST_V 357 (3) History of Mexico
Description: Examines themes in the last five hundred years of Mexican history, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources and the use of a variety of texts that may include letters, diaries, paintings, photographs, novels, and movies.
Title: HIST_V 358 (3) State and Society in 20th century Cuba
Description: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life.
Title: HIST_V 359 (3) A History of Brazil: From Colony to Nation
Description: The cultural and political history of Brazil, from the earliest arrival of the Portuguese to Brazil's emergence as one of the economic powerhouses of the twenty-first century.
Title: HIST_V 362 (3) The Islamic Golden Age
Description: Political, economic, social, and cultural history of the premodern Islamic World and its global connections during the Abbasid Caliphate, with attention to the relevance of this past to our contemporary world.
Title: HIST_V 363 (3) Europe in the Early Middle Ages
Description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 400 through about 1000 CE.
Title: HIST_V 364 (3) Europe in the Late Middle Ages
Description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 1000 CE through the fourteenth century.
Title: HIST_V 365 (3) Europe During the Renaissance
Description: The interplay between new and traditional ideas, styles, and institutions from the fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth century, with emphasis upon the relationship of social, economic, and political factors to intellectual and cultural change.
Title: HIST_V 366 (3) Europe During the Reformation
Description: An examination of European history that place both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era.
Title: HIST_V 367 (3) Europe in the Age of the Enlightenment
Description: Europe during the age of the Enlightenment, from the end of the religious wars to the French Revolution, with emphasis on political, social, cultural, and intellectual changes in their global context.
Title: HIST_V 368 (3) Europe in the 19th Century
Description: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century.
Title: HIST_V 369 (3) Europe, 1900-1950
Description: Europe in the first half of the twentieth century. Themes include the imperialist system, two world wars and their aftermaths, political and social movements of the interwar years, the Depression, and the crisis of liberal democracy.
Title: HIST_V 370 (3) Europe Since 1950
Description: Europe since the middle of the twentieth century. Themes include the Cold War, the development of separate social and political systems in Western and Eastern Europe, the emergence of the welfare state, and the problems of European integration.
Title: HIST_V 373 (3) History of Hong Kong
Description: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 373 or ASIA 373. Equivalency: ASIA 373
Title: HIST_V 376 (3-6) Modern Japanese History Since 1830
Description: Meanings of modernity, from the establishment of a nation-state to the creation of a colonial empire, postwar occupation, modern politics and global influence. Social change, including civil protest, mass culture, censorship and expression, and gender, sexuality, ethnicity and race.
Title: HIST_V 377 (3) History of Cantonese Worlds
Description: The history, culture, languages, and identities of the multi-faceted Cantonese worlds, in the context of Chinese history and the Cantonese diaspora. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 377 or ASIA 323. Equivalency: ASIA 323 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 378 (3) History of Early China
Description: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 378 or ASIA 320. Equivalency: ASIA 320
Title: HIST_V 379 (3) History of Later Imperial China
Description: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 379 or ASIA 340. Equivalency: ASIA 340
Title: HIST_V 380 (3-6) The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution
Description: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.
Title: HIST_V 381 (3) Imperialism and Nationalism in Southeast Asia
Description: The history of European imperial rule, the forms of resistance to it, and the formation of nationalist movements in Southeast Asia. The countries studied include Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Burma, and Thailand.
Title: HIST_V 382 (3) Post-Colonial Southeast Asia
Description: The history of the Japanese occupation, wars of independence, international relations of the independent nation-states, and internal armed conflicts. Special attention will be paid to the wars in Vietnam, Indonesia, and East Timor.
Title: HIST_V 383 (3) Foundations of Sikh Traditions
Description: Sikh religious beliefs, practices, institutions, and thought. Emphasis on the history of the Sikh Gurus and their writings, and the larger social and cultural forces within which the tradition developed.
Title: HIST_V 384 (3) The Making of Modern Sikhism
Description: Historical, social, and cultural forces that shaped Sikh religious beliefs, practices, institutions, and thought in the modern period, including both colonial and post-colonial contexts and the transnational Sikh community.
Title: HIST_V 385 (3) India from Raj to Republic
Description: Exploration of the rise of the East India Company as territorial power, the formation of a colonial society in India, competing responses to British rule, the struggle for independence, and the legacies of partition.
Title: HIST_V 386 (3-6) Korea Since 1860
Description: An examination of the political, economic, social, and cultural transformations of Korea since the late nineteenth century. Topics include the end of the Choson Dynasty, the history of Japanese colonial rule, the Korean war, and the two Koreas in the international system.
Title: HIST_V 387 (3) Voices from Medieval India
Description: History of medieval India explored through different stories from and about India's pre-modern past. Studies trends in society, religion, politics, and material life to reveal the dynamism of this period and to challenge simplified narratives of Hindu-Muslim confrontation.
Title: HIST_V 388 (3) India in the Early Modern World: Kings, Courtesans, and Saints
Description: History of India during the period of Mughal rule (roughly 1500-1750). Studies the role of India and the Mughals within the global dynamics of the early modern world.
Title: HIST_V 389 (6) The Sikhs: History, Religion and Society
Description: A historical study of the social and cultural forces that helped shape Sikh religious beliefs and ritual practices over the past four centuries. In dealing with the evolution of Sikh identity, attention will be given to Sikh ideals, social organization, religious institutions and sacred literature.
Title: HIST_V 390 (3-6) Topics in History
Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the program website https://history.ubc.ca/courses/ for more information. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 391 (3) Human Rights in World History
Description: Changing ideas about humanity and rights. Considers the relationship between human rights and the nation-state, imperialism, and capitalism. Assesses the efforts to end large-scale human rights violations and the role of the United Nations.
Title: HIST_V 392 (3) Scientific Revolution: Circulation of Knowledge in the Early Modern World
Description: The profound transformation of knowledge about the world in the context of the first global encounter of civilizations between 1450 and 1800. Explores the foundations for modern science.
Title: HIST_V 393 (3) Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
Description: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 393 or PHIL 360. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 393 or PHIL 360. Equivalency: PHIL 360
Title: HIST_V 394 (3) Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
Description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 394 or PHIL 364. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 394 or PHIL 364. Equivalency: PHIL 364
Title: HIST_V 395 (3) The Nuclear Century: Scientists, Atoms, and the World Order Since 1900
Description: Science and the military-industrial complex; quantum and relativistic revolutions in physics; nuclear energy and weapons of mass destruction; international tensions, environmental damage, and global perils.
Title: HIST_V 396 (3) Environmental History of North America
Description: Overview of land use and environmental change in Canada and the United States; examines ideas and practices that shaped indigenous and non-indigenous resource exploitation, management, and activism to the end of the twentieth century.
Title: HIST_V 397 (3) Environmental History of the Modern World
Description: Major themes in global environmental history and historiography since 1500, with a particular focus on the nineteenth through twenty-first centuries.
Title: HIST_V 398 (3) The History of Modern Medicine
Description: The history of health and disease in the modern world, focusing in particular on the emergence and history of modern biomedicine.
Title: HIST_V 399 (3-6) Theory and Practice of History
Description: Approaches to the history of historical inquiry, with particular attention to theoretical and methodo-logical debates among historians. Recommended for history majors. Not open to Department of History honours students.
Title: HIST_V 400 (3) The Practice of Oral History
Description: The practice, ethics, and politics of oral history. Provides research training, where students design and complete projects based on oral history interviews.
Title: HIST_V 401 (3) Seafaring in the Age of Sail
Description: Humankind's encounter with its ocean frontier through exploration, trading, fishing, whaling, piracy, and naval warfare from 1400 to 1850.
Title: HIST_V 402 (3) Problems in International Relations
Description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.
Title: HIST_V 403 (3) Seminar in the History of International Relations
Description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 404 (3) The First World War
Description: WWI as a global war; cultural history and legacy; impact of imperialism on the war; military technology.
Title: HIST_V 405 (3) Diplomacy and Conflict in the Middle East, 1914 to the Present
Description: International relations in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Ottoman Empire, with special attention to the conflicts between Jews of Palestine/Israel and their Arab neighbours.
Title: HIST_V 406 (3) The Second World War
Description: Precursors and consequences of the war; military, political, cultural, social, and economic histories of how the war shaped and reflected its global context. Themes include totalitarianism, genocide, and imperialism and decolonization.
Title: HIST_V 408 (3) U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II
Description: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.
Title: HIST_V 409 (3) U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945
Description: U.S. foreign policy and international history. Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.
Title: HIST_V 411 (3-6) History of Canadian International Relations
Description: Themes include Canadian relations with the United States and British Empire, the emergence of Canada in international organizations such as the United Nations and NATO, and Canada's role in the development of international law, international trade, and human rights systems.
Title: HIST_V 412 (6) The American Impact on Canada
Description: An examination of the influence of the United States' rise to continental, hemispheric, and world power upon Canada in the areas of economics, defence, and foreign policy.
Title: HIST_V 413 (3) Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada
Description: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum.
Title: HIST_V 414 (3) Constitutions in Canadian History: From Pre-Contact to the Charter of Rights
Description: European precedents, Colonial self-government, Canadian Confederation, and issues such as gay rights, abortion, and First Nations land rights.
Title: HIST_V 415 (3) History of Vancouver
Description: Selected themes in the history of Vancouver, exploring how the study of the past illuminates or explains major debates in the city today.
Title: HIST_V 418 (3) The 1960s in Global Perspective
Description: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict.
Title: HIST_V 419 (3) Crime and Punishment in Canadian History
Description: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada.
Title: HIST_V 420 (3-6) Topics in Canadian History
Description: May include immigration, French-English relations, the growth of the state, health and welfare, or the family.
Title: HIST_V 421 (6-12) Honours Tutorial
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 423 (3) Economic and Business History of Modern Japan
Description: From 1800 to the present; emphasis on the business strategies of Japan's largest companies; attention also to broader economic topics such as international trade, government policy, social impact of industry, business and politics, labour, and post-1971 multi-nationalism.
Title: HIST_V 424 (3) Economic History of the Pre-Modern World
Description: Historic origins and drivers of economic growth around the globe.
Title: HIST_V 425 (6) War and Society
Description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history.
Title: HIST_V 432 (6) International Relations in the Twentieth Century
Description: History of international relations from the beginning of the twentieth century to the present. Questions of war, peace, balance of power, and the evolution of the international system in global economic, cultural, and social contexts.
Title: HIST_V 433 (6) Fourth-Year Honours Seminar
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 435 (3) Gender and Sexuality in the Modern U. S.
Description: Gender roles and gender relations from the Gilded Age to the present day. Topics include political movements such as suffrage and feminism; labour and recreation; marriage, family, and children's socialization; sexuality; and popular culture.
Title: HIST_V 436 (6) European Social History
Description: A study of the changes in economic activity, social structure, family life, religious attitudes, and popular behaviour which accompanied the transformation of Europe from a pre-industrial to an industrial society.
Title: HIST_V 439 (3) Politics and Culture in Fin-de-Si�cle Europe (1890-1914)
Description: Explores relationships between politics, culture, and social change in Europe. Topics include the changing role of intellectuals: literary aestheticism, painting, design and the city, origins of psychology.
Title: HIST_V 440 (3) History of Global Health
Description: The emergence of global health since 1800. Medical and social response to infectious diseases and epidemics, the ethical foundations of global health, and the relationship among health, colonialism, international collaboration, and the developing world.
Title: HIST_V 441 (3) History of the Holocaust
Description: A study of the systematic attempt to destroy European Jewry during the Nazi regime, 1933-1945. Topics of special importance include: the motivations and behaviour of the perpetrators; the reactions of the victims; the roles of bystanders.
Title: HIST_V 443 (3) History of North American Children and Youth
Description: Children's history from settler days to the present. Topics include education, work and play, ideologies of childhood and adolescence, children's material and popular culture, and differences of identity based on region, class, race, and gender.
Title: HIST_V 444 (3) Slave Societies in the Americas
Description: A comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline, in the various cultures of the Americas.
Title: HIST_V 446 (3-6) Topics in U.S. Cultural History
Description: 
Title: HIST_V 447 (3) Selected Topics in United States History
Description: Examines in depth a significant period, theme, or topic in the history of the United States. Possible subjects include The West, the Great Depression, the Sixties, and Class, Race, and Gender.
Title: HIST_V 449 (12) Honours Essay
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 450 (3-6) Selected Topics in Latin American History
Description: A study in depth of one major topic (such as the Cuban Revolution or Peronismo) in the recent history of Latin America.
Title: HIST_V 451 (3) Family and Community in Latin America
Description: The role of family and community from the colonial period to the present. Emergence of the nation state as it affected community and family structures.
Title: HIST_V 453 (3) Class and Culture in Latin America
Description: The relationship between culture and class formation from the late colonial period to the present.
Title: HIST_V 455 (3) Gender and Sexuality in Latin America
Description: The construction of gender ideologies and gendered and sexual identities, including masculine, feminine, and transgendered, in modern Latin America. [3-0-0]
Title: HIST_V 456 (3) Race in the Americas
Description: Legacies of African, European, and Asian migrations, and colonial encounters with indigenous peoples in the Americas. Includes the creation of racial categories, the making of transnational and transracial families, and the emergence of race-based social and cultural movements.
Title: HIST_V 460 (3) Revolution and Resistance in the Third World
Description: Revolutionary movements in the Third World during the second half of the twentieth century; the radicalisation of anticolonial nationalism; the impact of anticolonial radicalism in the developed world; the decline of Marxism as a revolutionary inspiration.
Title: HIST_V 464 (3) First Contacts in the Pacific
Description: An interdisciplinary history of early European contact with the Indigenous peoples of the northwest coast of North America and the Pacific Islands.
Title: HIST_V 466 (3) Topics in Indigenous History of Canada
Description: Selected interdisciplinary topics in the history of Canada's Indigenous peoples after European contact, including historical demography, economic interdependency, missionary encounters, gender relations, and interactions with colonial powers and the nation state. Recommended: HIST 302 or other background in the field. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 467 (3) Topics in Indigenous History of the United States
Description: Interdisciplinary topics in the history of the United States' Indigenous peoples from before European contact. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 468 (3) Topics in Comparative Indigenous History
Description: Comparative interdisciplinary analysis of selected topics in Indigenous history in North America and beyond. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 469 (3) Aboriginal Title in British Columbia: History and Legacy
Description: Colonial land policy, Indigenous resistance and organizing, treaties, and court decisions. Some previous knowledge of Indigenous history is strongly recommended.
Title: HIST_V 470 (6) Seminar in Medieval History
Description: Annually changing topics of medieval studies with special attention to research methods on primary sources.
Title: HIST_V 473 (3) Women in the Middle Ages
Description: A study of women's roles in the family, society, law, religion, the economy, and literature from about 500 to 1500 CE.
Title: HIST_V 474 (3) Ideas and Religions of the Middle Ages
Description: A survey and exploration of the development, interpenetration, conflict, and transformation of various intellectual and religious traditions during the Middle Ages.
Title: HIST_V 475 (3) Documenting Punjabi Canada
Description: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 476 (3) Law and Society in the Middle Ages
Description: The history of law in the Middle Ages, including English common law, civil (Roman) law, and canon law, and how changes in both medieval law and society affected the development of each.
Title: HIST_V 477 (3) Constitutional History of Medieval Europe
Description: The evolution of political institutions, the emergence of royal governments as well as representative assemblies and urban republic and conflicts within and among them leading to the emergence of modern structures.
Title: HIST_V 478 (3) Medieval Portraits and Personalities
Description: The lives of leading and controversial figures in the Middle Ages and the means by which they have portrayed themselves and been portrayed by others.
Title: HIST_V 479 (3-6) Cultural History of Imperial China
Description: An in-depth examination of the construction, transmission, and transformation of Chinese culture(s) prior to 1800. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 479 or ASIA 440. Equivalency: ASIA 440.
Title: HIST_V 480 (6) Social History of Modern China
Description: Changes and continuities in Chinese society and culture from the late imperial period to the present; rural and urban life, social stratification, social movements and ideology, family and community, popular beliefs and cultural values.
Title: HIST_V 481 (3) Education and Society in Modern China
Description: The relationship between education and society in China since 1600; classical learning and the civil service examination system; popular literacy; sino-foreign interactions in education; education and gender; nationalism and education; the education revolution in China after 1949.
Title: HIST_V 482 (3) Chinese Migration
Description: This history of Chinese migrations from the founding of the state to the present day. Migration is used as a focus through which to examine some key themes of Chinese history; ethnicity, boundary creation, economic growth and international relations.
Title: HIST_V 483 (3) Asian Migrations to the Americas
Description: Examines both the historical and contemporary contexts for migration from Asia to Canada and the Americas.
Title: HIST_V 484 (3) East Asian Military systems and warfare China
Description: Confucian societies are often thought of as ones in which the brush is mightier than the sword. In fact the military has been a crucial factor in East Asia, and warfare has been the engine which has driven many of the most significant changes in East Asian history. This course will look at the evolution of East Asian military systems, and at the impact of recurrent warfare on East Asia societies.
Title: HIST_V 485 (3) Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver
Description: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities.
Title: HIST_V 487 (3) History of Alternative and Complementary Medicine: Acupuncture to Yoga
Description: Alternative and complementary healing in history, including Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), yoga, meditation, and alternative drug therapies. Specific themes may vary from year to year.
Title: HIST_V 488 (3-6) Special Topics in Asian History
Description: 
Title: HIST_V 490 (3) Seminar for Majors in History
Description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 491 (3) Science and the Enlightenment
Description: Examines the relationship between science and society in the long eighteenth century. Topics include empiricism, classification, academies, print culture, and voyages of exploration.
Title: HIST_V 493 (3) History and Social Relations of Modern Sciences.
Description: Science and society in the 19th to 21st Centuries. [3-0-0]
Title: HIST_V 494 (3) Machines, Media, and Modernity: Frankenstein to Cinema
Description: The cultural contexts and consequences of science and nineteenth century technology. European and North American developments.
Title: HIST_V 495 (3) Evolution and the Sciences of Mind, Brain, and Behaviour
Description: Examines how Darwin's theory of evolution changed the investigation of human nature. Questions will be historical and scientific, but will also concern the social, ethical, and existential stakes raised by the human mind as a product of evolution.
Title: HIST_V 500 (3) Readings in Canadian History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 505 (3) Readings in American History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 510 (3) Readings in British History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 520 (3) Readings in Medieval History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 525 (3) Professional Development for Historians
Description: Offers essential skills for academic and non-academic paths in the historical profession as well as identifying alternative career possibilities for historians. Offers essential skills for academic and non-academic paths in the historical profession as well as identifying alternative career possibilities for historians. Restricted to students in the following programs: PhD in History, MA in History This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 530 (3) Readings in French History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 535 (3) Readings in Central European History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 540 (3) Readings in Russian and East European History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 547 (3-12) Readings: Special Topics in History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 548 (3-12) Historiography
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 549 (12) Master's Thesis
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 550 (3) Readings in Early Modern European History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 554 (3) Readings in Modern European History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 558 (3) Readings in Comparative Asian History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 560 (3) Readings in Chinese History (to 1911)
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 561 (3) Readings in Chinese History (post-1911)
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 563 (3) Methodology and Sources in Chinese History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 566 (3) Readings in 20th-Century Japanese History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 568 (3) Readings in Early Modern Japanese and World History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 569 (3) Methodology and Sources in Japanese History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HIST_V 570 (3) Seminar in Japanese History
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: HUNU_V 500 (3) Research Methods in Human Nutrition
Description: Experimental design, methods of survey research, nutritional epidemiology, clinical research, and laboratory animal research. Issues such as animal models, ethics in animal and human research, statistical methods, and preparation of written reports and manuscripts, etc., will be addressed. Required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Human Nutrition. [3-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HUNU_V 503 (3) Current Issues in Nutrition and Metabolism
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HUNU_V 505 (3) Current Issues in Applied Nutrition
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: HUNU_V 510 (3) Nutrition Assessment Across the Lifespan

Title: HUNU_V 515 (3) Business & Entrepreneurship in Dietetics

Title: HUNU_V 540 (4.5) Advances in Food Theory and Applications

Title: HUNU_V 541 (3) Food Provision and Management in Dietetics
