Title: LAIS_V 620 (6) Advanced Study in Major Area
Description: Prerequisite: All of LAIS 605, LAIS 607 and one of LAIS 608, LAIS 609. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LAIS_V 621 (6) Advanced Study in Minor Area
Description: Prerequisite: All of LAIS 605, LAIS 607 and one of LAIS 608, LAIS 609. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LAIS_V 699 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 100 (3) Introduction to Language and Linguistics
Description: Study of language as a universal and uniquely human cognitive system: What universals do all languages share and how do languages differ? An investigation of sound systems, word-building, grammatical principles, language change, dialect variation, language acquisition, neurolinguistics. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.
Title: LING_V 101 (3) Languages of the World
Description: A survey of the linguistic map of the world, examining how languages are genetically classified and how different languages evolve. Principles underlying different writing systems and the decipherment of historical documents. Issues of languages in contact, minority language endangerment, language death and the role of English as a world language. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linguistics or speech sciences.
Title: LING_V 140 (3) Challenging Language Myths
Description: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be granted for only one of LING 140 or ENGL 140. Equivalency: ENGL 140 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 142 (3) Language and Technology
Description: Fundamentals of how computational linguistics makes possible automated speech with Siri, automated translation with Google Translate, and related internet and social-media technologies. Issues in ethics and language-data ownership. Emphasis on applications relating to Arts disciplines. No computing background required.
Title: LING_V 170 (3) Introduction to How to Learn a Language
Description: Skills and strategies for second language acquisition, through the foundations of pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and pragmatics, connected to the practical, social, and personal challenges of language learning.
Title: LING_V 200 (3) Linguistic Theory and Analysis I
Description: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.
Title: LING_V 201 (3) Linguistic Theory and Analysis II
Description: Introduction to grammatical analysis; morphology, syntax, semantics; synchronic analysis and description with illustrations from various languages. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.
Title: LING_V 209 (3) Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
Description: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences, with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.
Title: LING_V 222 (3) Language Acquisition
Description: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.
Title: LING_V 242 (3) Computational Tools for Linguistic Analysis
Description: Practical skills for analyzing language using the Python programming language and relevant packages. Prerequisite: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170, LING 200, LING 201, ENGL 330, ENGL 331. Recommended: LING 201 and CPSC 103 or CPSC 110 (or other programming experience).
Title: LING_V 270 (3) Introduction to Studies in Second Language Acquisition
Description: Linguistic systems that learners of an additional language develop as they approximate towards the target language, and key questions about what this 'interlanguage' system reveals about how we learn languages. Prerequisite: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170.
Title: LING_V 300 (3) Studies in Grammar
Description: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages. Prerequisite: LING 201.
Title: LING_V 308 (3) The Languages of Africa
Description: Linguistic survey of the languages of Africa, including typological and historical connections between languages, individual and comparative surveys of sound systems, word structures, sentence structures, semantics, and sociolinguistic properties of a representative selection of languages. Credit will only be granted for one of LING 308 or AFST 308. Equivalency: AFST 308
Title: LING_V 311 (3) Studies in Phonology
Description: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages. Prerequisite: LING 200.
Title: LING_V 313 (3) Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Speech Science
Description: The articulatory and acoustic properties of speech production and perception, including practice in phonetic transcription, instrumental recording, and the analysis of normal speech. Prerequisite: LING 200.
Title: LING_V 314 (3) Instrumental Phonetics
Description: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination. Prerequisite: LING 200. Recommended: LING 313
Title: LING_V 315 (3) Sociolinguistics
Description: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon. Credit will be granted for only one of LING 445 or 315. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201.
Title: LING_V 319 (3) Historical Linguistics
Description: How and why languages change over time, and how languages can be grouped into families based on historical relationships. Methods of comparative and internal reconstruction of phonological, morphological, syntactic, semantic change. Social factors in language change. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: LING 200 and LING 201.
Title: LING_V 327 (3) Introduction to Semantics
Description: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics. Prerequisite: LING 201.
Title: LING_V 333 (3) Research Methods for Linguistics
Description: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201.
Title: LING_V 342 (3) Computational Models of Language
Description: A re-examination of major areas of linguistics from a computational perspective, including popular formalisms and algorithms associated with morphology, syntax, semantics, and discourse. Prerequisite: LING 242 and one of LING 201, ENGL 331 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 251, STAT 302, MATH 302, PSYC 218.
Title: LING_V 345 (3) Pragmatics
Description: Selected topics in pragmatics and information structure, including variations in their cross-linguistic expression and the corresponding influence of sentence form on context. Prerequisite: One of LING 201, ENGL 331, PHIL 220, PHIL 222.
Title: LING_V 405 (3) Morphology
Description: Analytic and theoretical consideration of the interrelation of word formation, sound patterning, and meaningful sentence structure. Not offered every year. Prerequisite: All of LING 300, LING 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 410 (3) Advanced Phonology
Description: Current issues in phonological theory. Prerequisite: LING 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 415 (3) Language Across Time, Geography, and Society
Description: A cross-linguistic exploration of language change, discussing theories, data, and methods. Topics can include change across historical time periods, lifespan; change across regions, within areas; change due to language contact and other social and cultural factors. Prerequisite: One of LING 319, LING 315, LING 445, ENGL 318, ENGL 319, ENGL 324 and two of LING 300, LING 311, LING 313, LING 327.
Title: LING_V 420 (3) Introduction to Linguistics
Description: General background to linguistic studies; the different approaches to the analysis of languages; synchronic and diachronic linguistics; phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours program in Linguistics.
Title: LING_V 421 (3) Advanced Syntax
Description: Current issues in syntactic theory. Prerequisite: LING 300.
Title: LING_V 425 (3) Advanced Semantics
Description: Current issues in semantic theory. Prerequisite: One of LING 327, PHIL 220, PHIL 222. A basic introduction to syntax is recommended (e.g., LING 100, LING 201, or ENGL 331). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 430 (3-6) Honours Seminar in Linguistics
Description: Research papers on general linguistic topics to be read and discussed.
Title: LING_V 431 (3) Field Methods I
Description: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment. Prerequisite: All of LING 300, LING 311.
Title: LING_V 432 (3) Field Methods II
Description: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment. Prerequisite: LING 431.
Title: LING_V 433 (3) Native Languages of the Americas
Description: Survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas. Study of the basis of genetic classification and areal similarities. The structure of representative languages will be presented and contrasted. The present status of American Indian languages will be considered. Note: this course is not necessarily offered every year.
Title: LING_V 436 (3) Community-based Language Research
Description: Research methods and partnerships, ethical paradigms, the social, cultural and historical context of language research, and the relation of language research to pedagogy, policy and planning.
Title: LING_V 440 (3) Language as a Social Instrument
Description: Language as a tool that shapes and is shaped by technology, media, politics and power relations in society. Considers multiple levels of linguistic structure from a cross-linguistic perspective. Prerequisite: All of LING 200, LING 201. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 447 (3-12) Topics in Linguistics
Description: A capstone course for Linguistics and Speech Sciences majors, normally taken after three years of study. Individual sections will differ substantially; see online Course List for detailed descriptions and prerequisites. May be repeated for credit when content is different.
Title: LING_V 448 (3-6) Directed Studies
Description: Supervisor and topic chosen by mutual agreement between student and Linguistics faculty member. Department Advisor approval is required.
Title: LING_V 449 (6) Honours Essay
Description: 
Title: LING_V 451 (3) Acquisition of Phonology
Description: Development of the phonological system in typical first language acquisition from the perspective of diverse linguistic topics. Phonetic transcription of child speech. Prerequisite: All of LING 222, LING 311.
Title: LING_V 452 (3) Acquisition of Syntax
Description: Central issues in the first language acquisition of syntax, including early lexical and semantic development, acquisition of morphology, and syntactic development (e.g., word order, questions). Prerequisite: All of LING 222, LING 300.
Title: LING_V 469 (3) Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
Description: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.
Title: LING_V 502 (4) Formal Foundations of Syntax & Semantics
Description: Conceptual underpinnings of the study of sentence structure and meaning; core issues in syntax and semantics; the place of syntax and semantics in a model of grammar; interface issues. Prerequisite: LING 520 and 525 are recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 503 (3) Topics in Language Acquisition
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 505 (3-6) Issues in Morphological Theory and Analysis
Description: Morphology from both historical and theoretical perspectives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 507 (4) Formal Foundations of Phonetics & Phonology
Description: Conceptual underpinnings of the study of speech sounds; core issues in phonetics and phonology; the place of phonetics and phonology in a model of grammar; interface issues. Prerequisite: LING 508 and 510 are recommended. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 508 (3) Phonetic Theory & Analysis
Description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in linguistic phonetics; instrumental analysis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 510 (3) Phonological Theory and Analysis
Description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in phonological theory. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 511 (3) Topics in Phonology
Description: Prerequisite: LING 510. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 512 (3) Topics in Phonetics & Phonology
Description: Advanced topics in phonetics and phonology; in-depth analysis of specific issues and problems. Prerequisite: LING508,LING510 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 513 (3) Topics in Phonetics
Description: Prerequisite: LING 508. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 518 (3-9) Advanced Research Seminar
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 519 (3-6) Problems in Comparative and Historical Linguistics
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 520 (3) Syntactic Theory and Analysis
Description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in syntactic theory. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 521 (3) Topics in Syntax
Description: Prerequisite: LING 520. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 522 (3) Topics in Syntax and Semantics
Description: Advanced topics in syntax and semantics; in-depth analysis of specific issues and problems. Prerequisite: LING520,LING525 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 525 (3) Semantic Theory and Analysis
Description: Discussion and critical analysis of current issues in semantic theory. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 527 (3) Topics in Semantics
Description: Prerequisite: LING 525. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 530 (3-12) Linguistic Problems in a Special Area
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 531 (3) Field Methods in Linguistics I
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 532 (3) Field Methods in Linguistics II
Description: Prerequisite: LING 531 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 533 (3-6) Indian Languages of the Northwest
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 538 (3-6) Seminar on Language Acquisition in Children
Description: Linguistic analysis of data from children learning a first language. Intensive examination of a topic that will vary each year dealing with advanced research into phonological, syntactic, and semantic aspects of language acquisition. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 545 (3-6) Problems in Sociolinguistics
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 546 (3-6) Directed Reading in Topics related to Linguistics
Description: The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 548 (0) Major Essay
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 549 (3-18) Master's Thesis
Description: The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 560 (3) Managing and Preserving Linguistic Data
Description: Theory and practice of research data management and preservation with an emphasis on linguistic and language data. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: LING_V 649 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MGMT_V 100 (3) Introduction to Business
Description: Introduction to the Faculty of Management and traditional areas of business including accounting, economics, finance, marketing, organizational behaviour, operations, business policy, information systems and entrepreneurship. Identifies the steps needed to build and manage successful local, national, and international competitive businesses and organizations. Introduces ethical and policy decisions faced by businesses, organizations and governments. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MGMT_V 110 (3) Introduction to Management Thought and Social Responsibility
Description: Introduces management thought in business and organizations. Utilizes critical thinking in socially and ethically responsible decisions at a corporate and personal level. Includes managing responsibly through people, mass production, ethical and socially-responsible practices. Covers start-ups, entrepreneurs, family business, non-profit/for-profit organizations and governments in global regions. Credit will be granted for only one of MGMT 110 or MGMT 200. [3-0-0] Equivalency: MGMT 200 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MGMT_V 200 (3) Introduction to Management Thought and Social Responsibility
Description: Introduces management thought in business and organizations. Utilizes critical thinking in socially and ethically responsible decisions at a corporate and personal level. Includes managing responsibly through people, mass production, ethical and socially-responsible practices. Covers start-ups, entrepreneurs, family business, non-profit/for-profit organizations and governments in global regions. Credit will be granted for only one of MGMT 200 or MGMT 110. [3-0-0] Equivalency: MGMT 110 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 201 (3) Technical Communication
Description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Manufacturing Engineering Program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. Equivalency: APSC 201 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 230 (4) Manufacturing Engineering Laboratory
Description: Theory, operational constraints, and problem solving in traditional manufacturing processes. Casting, heat treatment, bulk deformation (i.e. rolling, extrusion, drawing), machining, joining, and shaping of composites. Experiments in process and product characterization. [1-2-0; 1-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 261 (3) Thermodynamics
Description: Thermodynamic system and properties, thermodynamic processes; work and heat interactions. Conservation of energy and First Law, internal energy and enthalpy, the Second Law and entropy, application to manufacturing processes. [3-0-1] Prerequisite: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 158. Corequisite: MATH 255. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 265 (3) Machine Dynamics
Description: Classifications of mechanisms, velocity, acceleration and force analysis, graphical and computer-oriented vector and matrix methods, balancing, flywheels, gears, gear trains, cams. [3-0-2*] Prerequisite: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 158, PHYS 170. Corequisite: MATH 255. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 270 (3) Production Systems Management I
Description: Impact of operations in increasing productivity and reducing waste. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 330 (6) Manufacturing Engineering Project I
Description: Project-based, multi-step manufacturing engineering design and problem solving. [1-4-0; 1-4-0] Prerequisite: MANU 230. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 370 (3) Production Systems Management II
Description: Functional area of production and operations management. Decision-making, capacity planning, aggregate planning, inventory management, distribution planning, materials requirements planning and quality control. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MANU 270. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 378 (3) Engineering Materials II
Description: Materials selection for different design criteria; importance of shape and processing variables; computer software in selection. Credit will be granted for only one of MTRL 280 or MANU 378. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: APSC 278. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 380 (3) Manufacturing Processes I
Description: Correlation between material properties and processibility for practical engineering manufacturing routes. Calculations and design. Application of heat/mass/fluid transport, mechanics and thermodynamics to manufacturing processes. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: All of APSC 278, APSC 279, MTRL 264, MECH 260 and one of MANU 261, MTRL 250 and one of MECH 280, MTRL 263. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 386 (3) Industrial Automation
Description: Principle components of manufacturing automation, modelling of sensors-actuators and control systems, robotic programming, programmable logical control (PLC) systems and development of PLC ladder diagrams. [2-3*-1] Prerequisite: All of MANU 265, MATH 255. Corequisite: MANU 330. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 399 (1-6) Special Topics in Manufacturing Engineering
Description: Prerequisite: Third-year standing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 400 (1-9) Topics in Manufacturing Engineering
Description: [2-0-3] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 430 (6) Manufacturing Design Capstone Project
Description: Project-based, multi-step, multi-part Capstone design project involving manufacturing engineering design methods, problem solving. [1-4-0; 1-4-0] Prerequisite: MANU 330. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 450 (3) Biomedical Manufacturing
Description: Bulk and nanoscale manufacturing processes for biomedical devices, materials and therapeutics; drug delivery; host-tissue biomaterial interactions; surface modification of medical devices; sterilization techniques; good manufacturing processes; medical device regulation. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing or higher.
Title: MANU_V 453 (3) Additive Manufacturing Design
Description: Design tools and methods for additive manufacturing, complex digital geometry creation, computer aided design tools, additive manufacturing workflow development, producibility analysis, analysis of 3D data sets for suitability to additive manufacturing processes. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing or greater. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 455 (3) Factory Planning
Description: Resources planning, layout and logistics. Modular production and cyber-physical manufacturing systems in laboratory scale, virtual manufacturing and factory automation. [2-2-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 458 (3) Manufacturing for Clean Energy
Description: Manufacturing and the net-zero energy transition; renewable, low-carbon and sustainable energy and electricity generation; energy, electricity transport, storage and batteries; hydrogen economy; carbon capture utilization and storage (CCUS). [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third-year standing or greater. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 465 (3) AI and Machine Learning Applications in Manufacturing
Description: Artificial intelligence, machine learning techniques, Deep learning, Python libraries for machine learning, Basic signal processing techniques, Data Acquisition, Applications in Manufacturing, Use of sound to evaluate operation of CNC machinery, Use of AE sensor to evaluate metal 3D printing [3-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 480 (3) Manufacturing Processes II
Description: Numerical modelling of manufacturing processes, linkage between material, process, properties and product geometry, heat/mass transport, thermodynamics and design principles applied to practical engineering processes. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: MANU 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 481 (3) Manufacturing Processes III
Description: Integrating concepts of primary (casting), secondary (deformation), and tertiary (machining and surface treatment) processes and economic and environmental assessment. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: MANU 380. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 485 (3) Metal Cutting and Machine Tool Vibrations
Description: Metal cutting and grinding mechanics; prediction of force-torque-power in turning, drilling, milling and grinding operations. Machine tool vibrations, forced and self-excited vibrations in machining, experimental modal testing of machine tools, chatter, and stability. Credit will be granted for only one of MANU 485 or MECH 592. [3-1*-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 487 (3) Machine and Part Metrology
Description: Laser interferometer measurement of volumetric accuracy; error mapping, modelling and compensation of errors, rotation metrology, spindle accuracy. Part dimension and surface metrology. Metrology instruments: Coordinate measurement machine, surface profile meter, laser interferometer and ball bar. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: All of MANU 265, MATH 255, MECH 368. Corequisite: MANU 430. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MANU_V 499 (1-6) Special Topics in Manufacturing Engineering
Description: [2-2-0] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MRNE_V 400 (3-6) Directed Studies
Description: A research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student designed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Note: the supervisor may be teaching at the Marine Centre; or a member of faculty of WCUMSS whether at the Marine Centre as a research investigator or as one of the members of WCUMSS.
Title: MRNE_V 401 (6) Special Topics in Marine Biology
Description: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. It is expected that the course will generally be of a specialized nature and be at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.
Title: MRNE_V 402 (3-12) Special Topics in Marine Biology
Description: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. This course will be of a specialized nature and at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.
Title: MRNE_V 410 (6) Marine Invertebrate Zoology
Description: A survey of the marine phyla, with emphasis on the benthic fauna in the vicinity of the Marine Station. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.
Title: MRNE_V 411 (6) Comparative Invertebrate Embryology
Description: A comprehensive study of development of marine invertebrates available at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre, including all major phyla and most of the minor phyla. Prerequisite: course in invertebrates or embryology.
Title: MRNE_V 412 (6) Biology of Fishes
Description: Classification, physiology, ecology, behaviour and zoogeography of fishes with particular emphasis on those in the marine environment of the British Columbia coast. Prerequisite: A course in comparative vertebrate anatomy.
Title: MRNE_V 415 (3) Structure and Function in Marine Animals
Description: Principles of classification, evolution, morphology, biomechanics, physiology and biochemistry will be illustrated in representatives from a variety of animal phyla. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: Completion of second year in a biology program.
Title: MRNE_V 420 (6) Marine Phycology
Description: A survey of the marine algae, with emphasis on the benthic forms in the vicinity of the Marine Centre. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.
Title: MRNE_V 425 (3) Ecological Adaptations of Seaweeds
Description: Morphological, physiological, genetic and reproductive adaptations of seaweeds to their environments. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: Completion of second year in a biology program.
Title: MRNE_V 430 (6) Marine Ecology
Description: An analytical approach to biotic associations in the marine environment. Opportunities are provided for study of the intertidal realm in exposed and protected areas, and of beaches and estuaries in the vicinity of the Marine Centre; plankton studies and investigations of the subtidal and benthic environments by diving and dredging are envisaged.
Title: MRNE_V 435 (6) Introduction to Biological Oceanography
Description: An introduction to the biology of oceans, with supporting coverage of relevant physics and chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on plankton biology, community structure and life histories, and influencing environmental factors. Collections will be made from sheltered inlets, through Barkely Sound to offshore waters. The course will involve both field and laboratory. Prerequisite: [BIOL320, BIOL205]
Title: MRNE_V 437 (3) Population and Community Ecology of Marine Organisms
Description: Emphasis on interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physiochemical environment, and on biological diversity. [3-3-0] Prerequisite: Completion of second year in a biology program.
Title: MRNE_V 440 (6) Biology of Marine Birds
Description: Study of interrelationship of birds and the marine environment. Census techniques and observation of birds in the field will be emphasized. Prerequisite: Completion of a course in vertebrate zoology or permission of the instructor.
Title: MRNE_V 445 (6) Biology of Marine Mammals
Description: Survey course covering systematics and distribution of marine mammals, their sensory capabilities and physiology, with special emphasis on the Cetacea. The course will involve an independent field study. Prerequisite: Introductory vertebrate zoology.
Title: MRNE_V 480 (3) Seminars and Papers in Marine Science
Description: Instruction in the critical analysis of published research papers and of oral seminars. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: Completion of second year in a biology program.
Title: MRNE_V 501 (6) Special Topics
Description: 6 weeks. Offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists who are visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. The course will be of a specialized nature. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MRNE_V 502 (3) Special Topics
Description: 3 weeks. Offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists who are visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. The course will be of a specialized nature. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 201 (3) Technical Communication
Description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Materials Engineering Program. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150. Corequisite: MTRL 280. Equivalency: APSC201 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 250 (4) Thermodynamics of Materials I
Description: Heat and mass balances applied to materials engineering; thermodynamic principles applied to materials processing: heat of reaction, free energy, activity, phase equilibrium, reactions involving gases, Ellingham diagrams. [3-0-2]
Title: MTRL_V 251 (4) Thermodynamics of Materials II
Description: Behaviour of solutions, phase diagrams, electrochemistry, chemical potential and free energy diagrams applied to materials processing and thermodynamic modelling. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: MTRL 250.
Title: MTRL_V 263 (3) Transport Phenomena I - Fluid Mechanics
Description: Fluid statics; fluid mechanics; laminar and turbulent flow; equations of continuity and motion; boundary layers; flow in conduits and packed and fluidized beds; flow measurements. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 264 (3) Transport Phenomena II - Heat Transport
Description: Conduction, forced and natural convection, and radiation. Heat transfer with fluid flow, applications of heat exchange, and solidification of castings. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 280 (3) Materials in Design
Description: The process of materials selection for different design criteria; the importance of shape and processing variables; the use of computer software in the selection process. [2-0-3] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 320 (2) Management of Engineering Design
Description: Fundamental communication and inter- personal skills, as well as operational processes, that engineers require to effectively work in design teams. Concepts and best practices around project management tools and techniques, team dynamics, planning, and organization. [1-0-2]
Title: MTRL_V 340 (3) Manufacturing in Materials Engineering
Description: Manufacturing processes from a materials perspective; metal casting, heat treating processes, forming processes, machining, and joining. Role of manufacturing in microstructure and material properties development and on component performance. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 358 (3) Hydrometallurgy I
Description: Aqueous extraction of metals from ores and concentrates. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 359 (1) Hydrometallurgy I Laboratory
Description: Laboratory exercises on aqueous extraction of metals from ores and concentrates. [0-3*-0] Corequisite: MTRL 358. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 361 (4) Modelling of Materials Processes
Description: Mathematical and physical modelling of processes employed in the production of materials. The application of models to analyze, design and improve materials production. [3-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 363 (3) Transport Phenomena III - Mass Transport
Description: Mass transfer fundamentals, gas interdiffusivity, Sievert's law, Fick's laws, solid-state diffusion, steady and non-steady state diffusion, mass transfer in quiescence fluids. The application examples are related to metallurgical processes, green technologies, and the semiconductor industry. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 365 (3) Mechanical Behaviour of Materials
Description: Polycrystalline and single crystal deformation; dislocation theory; strengthening mechanisms; fracture mechanics; fatigue; high temperature deformation mechanisms. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 378 (3) Phase Transformations
Description: Solidification and solid state transformations; nucleation and growth processes; segregation and structure in castings; phase changes in steel; transformation diagrams; diffusion equations. [3-0-2*]
Title: MTRL_V 381 (1) Structure and Properties Laboratory
Description: Structure and properties of ferrous and non-ferrous metals; heat treatment; hardenability; metallography; age hardening. [0-3*-0] Corequisite: All of MTRL 365, MTRL 378. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 394 (4) Polymers
Description: The structure and properties of polymeric materials and reinforced polymers with emphasis on their engineering properties and applications. [3-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 424 (3) Aerospace Materials and Manufacturing
Description: Advanced materials and manufacturing in the framework of aerospace requirements and regulations, with a focus on processing of materials, including advanced metals and polymer composites, to produce aerospace structures and engine components. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 451 (3) Microstructural Analysis Laboratory
Description: Basic principles and techniques of microstructural analysis with particular reference to engineered materials including x-ray, SEM microprobe TEM and high energy electron analysis. [1-3*-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 455 (3) Economic Aspects of Materials Engineering
Description: Time value of money, cash flows, capital and operating cost estimation, financial decision making and relevant case studies. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 456 (3) Environmental Degradation of Materials
Description: Fundamental aspects of environmental degradation of metals (corrosion), ceramics, adn polymers, with an empasis on aqueous environments. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 458 (3) Hydrometallurgy II
Description: Leaching, purification, precipitation, regeneration; thermodynamics and kinetics of separation steps; electrochemical applications. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 460 (3) Monitoring and Optimization of Materials Processing
Description: Measurement systems for materials processing and evaluation, methods of data collection and analysis in materials engineering, materials processing monitoring and control, design of experiments for materials processing and optimization. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 466 (3) Engineering Project I
Description: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials. [1-0-5] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 467 (3) Engineering Project II
Description: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials. [1-0-5] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 469 (3) Casting Technology
Description: Various casting technologies related to the automotive and aerospace sectorswill be covered, including upstream liquid metal processing. [2-0-2]
Title: MTRL_V 472 (3) Welding and Joining of Materials
Description: Case studies addressing temperature modelling in welding and joining, material selection for welds and joints, calculation of properties for welds and joints, mechanical analysis of joints, and design of welding and joining procedures. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 475 (3) Microstructure Engineering
Description: Follows the production of metallurgical products, focusing on process design models used to describe solidification, recrystallization, and precipitation. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 478 (3) Electronic Materials
Description: Semiconductor materials, MOSFET structure, operation and applications in digital circuits, fabrication techniques, basic mask and fabrication flow design and semiconductor fabrication process theories at an entry level. [3-0-0]
Title: MTRL_V 484 (3) Materials for Aerostructures and Engines
Description: Engineering theory of aerospace structural material mix: metal alloys, ceramics, and polymer composites. Material requirements for weight-, damage tolerant-, cost efficient-design. Overview of material characterization, including fracture and fatigue. Statistical variability, material allowables, structural certification. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 485 (3) Failure of Materials
Description: Failure by excess deformation, fracture, fatigue, and environmental effects. Failure theories and case studies of engineering failures. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 486 (3) Nondestructive Evaluation
Description: Principles of test methods; inspection techniques and equipment; quantitative flaw evaluation; reliability analysis. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 494 (3) Composite Materials
Description: Understanding the properties and the mechanical behaviour of composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 495 (3) Biomaterials
Description: Engineered materials in medical applications with an emphasis on material properties, functionality, design, and material response in the biological environment. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 496 (3) Materials Sustainability
Description: Concepts of life cycle analysis, circular economy and critical materials. Project-based introduction to key concepts, calculations, and design. [2-0-2] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 497 (1-6) Special Topics in Materials Engineering
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 512 (3) Material Optimization for the Manufacture of Structural Metallic Components
Description: Phase transformations and strengthening of advanced engineering alloys (e.g. steels, aluminum, magnesium and titanium alloys) with particular emphasis on structure-property development relevant to the latest materials manufacturing technologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 515 (3) Advanced Simulation and Modelling Tools for Materials Manufacturing
Description: Mathematical modelling of manufacturing processes; Computer Aided Engineering tools; application examples will be drawn from a range of manufacturing operations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 517 (3) Case Studies in Advanced Materials Manufacturing
Description: The full spectrum of design encountered including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 550 (2-4) Metallurgical Thermodynamics
Description: Application of advanced thermodynamic principles in metallurgical processes. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 557 (3) Separation Science in Aqueous Metal Processing
Description: The theory of solvent extraction and ion exchange, membrane separations, chemical precipitation, electrochemical separations and other techniques for aqueous metal processing, applications from the metal processing literature. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 558 (3) Corrosion
Description: Modern theories relating to corrosion and corrosion protection of metals. Thermodynamic and kinetic phenomena, corrosion measurements, inhibition and passivation, design for corrosive environments, stress corrosion cracking theory. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 559 (3) Advanced Hydrometallurgy
Description: Advanced thermochemical modelling of hydrometallurgical unit operations to include extraction, separation, and recovery of base metals. Application to flow-sheet analysis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 562 (3) Finite Elements in Heat Transfer
Description: Application of the finite element method to heat transfer and solidification; steady state and transient heat conduction; latent heat evolution and radiation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 564 (3) Hydrometallurgical Reactor Design and Analysis
Description: Batch leaching kinetics, leaching mechanisms; statistical methods for design of multiparticle continuous leaching reactors; coupled heat and mass balances, mixing phenomena, redox and precipitation reactions, complex mineralogical feeds; heap and dump leaching. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 570 (3) Deformation of Crystalline Materials
Description: Nature and properties of lattice imperfections; dislocation theory and its use to describe work hardening, creep, structure of grain boundaries and other phenomena. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 575 (3) Advanced Phase Transformations
Description: Thermodynamic and kinetic bases for the theory of phase transformations in the condensed state. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 578 (3) Microstructural Evolution of Deformed Materials
Description: Physical mechanisms of microstructure evolution; structure, energy and mobilities of grain boundaries, grain boundary segregation, precipitation, recovery, recrystallization, grain growth; microstructure engineering of steels. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 579 (3) Physics of Microfabrication: Front End Processing
Description: Practical aspects, physical models, and simulations of Si-based nanofabrication processes such as oxidation, diffusion, ion implantation, chemical vapor deposition, etching, stress techniques. Semiconductor device physic basics will also be discussed. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 585 (3) Topics in Fracture Mechanics
Description: The equations and concepts of linear elastic fracture mechanics. Fracture toughness testing, statistical theories of fracture and proof testing, stress corrosion cracking and static fatigue. Acoustic emission and other nondestructive testing methods. Case studies of large scale fractures of pressure vessels and structures. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 588 (3) Electrochemical Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: Electrochemical interfaces; electrode reactions; thermodynamics; kinetics and transport processes in electrochemical systems; experimental techniques. Electrochemical reactors and processes; modelling, design and economics. Electrochemical technologies; electrosynthesis, batteries and fuel cells. Electro-metallurgy; electrowinning and refining of metals, corrosion, leaching and cementation. Equivalency: CHBE577, MMAT588 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 592 (2-6) Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering
Description: May be arranged on approval of the department head. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 593 (1-6) Directed Studies in Materials Engineering
Description: The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 594 (3) Advanced Composite Materials
Description: Processing and properties of advanced polymer based composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 595 (3) Advanced Biomaterials
Description: Formation and structure-function relations of biological materials, the interaction of tissue-synthetic biomaterials, advanced biomaterials design, biomimetic processing, and current progress in drug delivery systems and biomedical devices. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 596 (18) M.Sc. Thesis
Description: For M.Sc. Degree. Research studies in materials engineering. Honours/Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 597 (6) M.Eng. Project
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 598 (0) Seminar
Description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in metals and materials research. A required course for graduate students in metals and materials which carries no academic credit. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 599 (18) M.A.Sc. Thesis
Description: For M.A.Sc. Degree. Research studies in materials engineering. Honours/Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MTRL_V 699 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Description: Derivatives of elementary functions. Applications and modelling: graphing, optimization. High school calculus is strongly recommended.

Description: Functions, derivatives, optimization, growth and decay, discrete probability. Title: MATH_V 103 (3) Integral Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
Description: Antiderivatives and definite integrals, infinite series, applications to probability and dynamical systems. Title: MATH_V 104 (3) Differential Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
Description: Derivatives and rates of change, exponential and trigonometric functions, Newton's method, Taylor polynomials, maxima and minima, and graphing. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult�. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: High-school calculus and a score of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.
Title: MATH_V 105 (3) Integral Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
Description: Antiderivatives, the definite integral, techniques of integration, infinite series, partial derivatives, maxima and minima with constraints, discrete and continuous random variables. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
Title: MATH_V 110 (6) Differential Calculus
Description: Topics as for MATH 100, but including relevant topics from algebra, geometry, functions, trigonometry, logarithms, and exponentials. [3-0-1.5; 3-0-1.5] Prerequisite: A grade of 65% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

Description: Limits, derivatives, Mean Value Theorem and applications, elementary functions, optimization, Taylor series, approximation. Title: MATH_V 190 (4) Calculus Survey
Description: Functions, derivatives, integrals, curve sketching growth functions, volume calculations. Only for credit in the Faculty of Forestry. Students with credit for MATH 100, 102, 104, 120, 180, or 184 cannot in the same term or later terms obtain credit for MATH 190. [3-0-2] Prerequisite: Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and registration in the B.S.F. or B.Sc.N. programs.
Title: MATH_V 200 (3) Calculus III
Description: Analytic geometry in 2 and 3 dimensions, partial and directional derivatives, chain rule, maxima and minima, second derivative test, Lagrange multipliers, multiple integrals with applications. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
Title: MATH_V 210 (3) Introduction to Mathematical Computing
Description: Introduction to mathematical software and numerical methods. Numbers, arrays, functions, vectorization and iteration. Sequences and series, root finding, numerical integration, numerical methods for differential equations, systems of linear equations, mathematical graphics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
Title: MATH_V 215 (3) Elementary Differential Equations I
Description: First-order equations; linear equations; linear systems; Laplace transforms; numerical methods; trajectory analysis of plane nonlinear systems. Applications of these topics will be emphasized. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult�. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
Title: MATH_V 217 (4) Multivariable and Vector Calculus
Description: Partial differentiation, extreme values, multiple integration, vector fields, line and surface integrals, the divergence theorem, Green's and Stokes' theorems. Intended for students in Honours Physics and Engineering Physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [4-0-0] Prerequisite: A score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
Title: MATH_V 220 (3) Mathematical Proof
Description: Sets and functions; induction; cardinality; properties of the real numbers; sequences, series, and limits. Logic, structure, style, and clarity of proofs emphasized throughout. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) a score of 64% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 121, MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
Title: MATH_V 221 (3) Matrix Algebra
Description: Systems of linear equations, operations on matrices, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of symmetric matrices. This course is intended for first and second year students. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184, SCIE 001 or (b) advanced credit for MATH 100.
Title: MATH_V 223 (3) Honours Linear Algebra
Description: Matrices, eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonality, linear systems, applications. This course is intended for first and second-year students. Students who obtain credit for MATH 223 cannot in the same or later terms obtain credit for MATH 152 or MATH 221. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 120, MATH 121, SCIE 001 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 180, MATH 184 or (c) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 152, MATH 221.
Title: MATH_V 226 (3) Advanced Calculus I
Description: Functions of several variables: limits, continuity, differentiability; implicit functions; Taylor's theorem; extrema; Lagrange multipliers; multiple integration, Fubini's theorem; improper integrals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 121 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001. Corequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
Title: MATH_V 227 (3) Advanced Calculus II
Description: Parametrization of curves and surfaces; line and surface integrals; theorems of Green, Gauss, Stokes; applications to physics and/or introduction to differential forms. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 226. Prerequisite grade requirement: 68% in MATH226.
Title: MATH_V 230 (3) Marvels of Mathematics
Description: A variety of topics in mathematics, showcasing its beauty and utility. Intended for a general audience of students whose degrees have no mathematics requirements, but who may be curious about practical and recreational mathematics. Not for credit in the Faculty of Science. Students who obtain UBC credit for any other mathematics course cannot in the same or later years obtain credit for MATH 230. [3-0-0]
Title: MATH_V 253 (3) Multivariable Calculus
Description: Partial and directional derivatives; maxima and minima; Lagrange multipliers and second derivative test; multiple integrals and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
Title: MATH_V 254 (3) Multivariable and Vector Calculus for Mechanical Engineering
Description: Partial differentiation, extreme values, multiple integration, vector fields, line and surface integrals, the divergence and Stokes' theorems; applications to fluid mechanics: buoyancy, hydrostatic force, pipe flow, drag; applications to thermodynamics: work, entropy, heat transfer; numerical methods. Emphasis on mechanical engineering applications. [3-0-1*] Prerequisite: MATH 101 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: All of MECH 222, MECH 225.
Title: MATH_V 255 (3) Ordinary Differential Equations
Description: Review of linear systems; nonlinear equations and applications; phase plane analysis; Laplace transforms; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
Title: MATH_V 256 (3) Differential Equations
Description: Linear ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms, Fourier series and separation of variables for linear partial differential equations. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult�. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.
Title: MATH_V 257 (3) Partial Differential Equations
Description: Introduction to partial differential equations; Fourier series; the heat, wave and potential equations; boundary-value problems; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.
Title: MATH_V 258 (3) Differential Equations for Mechanical Engineering
Description: First-order equations; linear equations; linear systems; Laplace transforms; trajectory analysis of plane nonlinear systems; translational and rotational vibrations; applications to RLC circuit analysis; numerical and graphical methods. Emphasis on mechanical engineering applications. [3-0-1*] Prerequisite: MATH 101 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223. Corequisite: All of MECH 221, MECH 224.
Title: MATH_V 264 (1) Vector Calculus for Electrical Engineering
Description: Divergence, gradient, curl, theorems of Gauss and Stokes. Applications to Electrostatics and Magnetostatics. MATH 264 content is strongly coupled to BMEG 220 and ELEC 211 with topics and student evaluations weighted accordingly. Prerequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254. Corequisite: One of BMEG 220, ELEC 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: MATH_V 300 (3) Introduction to Complex Variables
Description: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, elementary functions, Cauchy's theorem and contour integration, Laurent series, poles and residues. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Corequisite: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 254, MATH 317.
Title: MATH_V 301 (3) Applied Analysis
Description: Integrals involving multi-valued functions, conformal mapping and applications, analytic continuation, Laplace and Fourier transforms. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 300, MATH 305. Corequisite: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.
Title: MATH_V 302 (3) Introduction to Probability
Description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. Title: MATH_V 303 (3) Introduction to Stochastic Processes
Description: Discrete-time Markov chains, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, renewal theory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 302, STAT 302.
Title: MATH_V 305 (3) Applied Complex Analysis
Description: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, contour integration, Laurent series, residues, integrals of multi-valued functions, Fourier transforms. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult� [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254.
