Title: PPGA_V 310 (3) Designing for Global Community Development
Description: Design methodologies for exploring global community development processes relating to achieving the global Sustainable Development Goals. Prerequisite: Second year standing or higher.
Title: PPGA_V 391 (1.5-9) Topics in Public Policy and Global Affairs
Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings respond to current policy debates, topics of emerging interest, and interest in specific regions or countries.
Title: PPGA_V 500 (3-6) Economics for Policy
Description: Fundamental principles of economics applied to public policy and global affairs. Credit will be granted for only one of PPGA 500 or both PPGA 501, PPGA 502 or both GPP 501, GPP 502. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 503 (3) Measurement and Data Analysis for Policy
Description: Fundamental quantitative tools for policy analysis and program evaluation, including measurement, data visualization, and regression analysis. Introduction of skills for the design and implementation of quantitative policy analysis. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 504 (3) Policy Analysis and Evaluation
Description: Fundamentals of policy analysis and program evaluation for a professional context. Standard tools of policy analysis, risk assessment, and evaluation to design policy interventions and implement monitoring and evaluation systems for effectiveness. Case studies for government, international organizations, and NGOs. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 505 (3) Domestic and Global Policy Processes
Description: Theories and frameworks related to policy-making processes at both the domestic and global levels. Agenda setting, policy formulation and stakeholder engagement, decision-making, policy implementation, and policy evaluation. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 506 (3) Public Management
Description: Governmental implementation and delivery of public policy. Variations in international practice, the growing interdependence of governments, firms and non-government organizations. Complexities of multi-level governance including control and accountability of governments. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 507 (3) Environmental Law and Policy Frameworks
Description: Environmental law and policy creation, implementation, and enforcement at the international, national, and sub-national levels. Evolution of environmental law and policy, legal institutions, and major areas of law relating to ecological sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 508 (3) Policy in Context
Description: Analytical tools for assessing policy in different cultural contexts, inter-cultural communication skills, ethics, and effective community engagement in policy work. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 509 (1.5) Communicating Policy
Description: The role of media, especially new media, in effectively communicating policy to stakeholders. Focus on communications formats including written, oral, and multimedia policy communications. Examples include policy briefs, presentations, and intercultural communications. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 510 (1.5) Professional Practice in Public Policy and Global Affairs
Description: Analysis of professional practice in policy and global affairs, including potential alignment with personal values, strengths, and education. Development of essential professional skills including teamwork and project management. Pass/Fail. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 511 (1.5) Leadership for Policy Professionals
Description: Practical leadership skills and competencies for policy professionals bridging theory to principles and practices in an interactive studio setting. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 514 (1.5-3) Research Design and Qualitative Methods
Description: Research design principles and ethics. Methods for qualitative data collection and analysis to inform policy decision making. Focus on participant-observation, interviewing, focus groups, content and gender-based analysis. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 520 (3) Economics of Poverty
Description: Micro-scale processes of development, including the challenges posed by persistent poverty, and ground-level development solutions. Measurement and empirical evaluation of development interventions and outcomes. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 521 (3) Development and Institutions
Description: Introduction to macro-level long-term development processes by which societies improve their standards of living. Development theories, historical drivers; present debates; when and how public policies can best enable economic development. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 522 (3) Development Discourses and Practices
Description: The meaning of development and micro/macro aspects of policy planning and implementation for development. The rise of development thought; assessment of the outcomes of development for different countries and communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 523 (3) Economic Change and Reforms in Asia
Description: Trajectories and current puzzles in East Asian political economy in Japan, Korea, China, and South East Asia. Political economic institutions, dynamics and sustainability; integration of China and India into the world economy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 524 (3) Legal Change and Sustainability Challenges in Asia
Description: Impact of legal reform efforts on political, socio-economic and cultural change in selected economies of Asia. Relationships between changes in legal institutions, doctrines, and processes. Addressing sustainability challenges in human, natural and built environments. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 525 (3) Social Policy Responses to Rapid Development
Description: Prevalent social issues in Asia. Policy responses in Asian countries have been formulated in education, housing, welfare, and public health in response to the social dislocation that accompanies rapid development. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 526 (3) Challenges of Urbanization
Description: Spatial development, housing, infrastructure and local environments and the administrative and regulatory implications of urbanization. Interactions between bio-physical requisites of urbanization and structures and processes of governance which shape their provision. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 527 (3) Corporate Social Responsibility
Description: Policy debates surrounding Corporate Social Responsibility including: voluntary regulation initiatives; responsibility to stakeholders in global supply chains; public-private partnerships; socially responsible investing; transparency; and protection of human rights. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 528 (3) Emerging Powers
Description: Contemporary power shifts in the global political economy, and the agendas and impact of emerging powers in global politics, economics and governance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 540 (3) Tools and Techniques for Sustainability Assessment
Description: Environmental and socio-economic outcomes of projects and policies including: systems modelling and dynamics; life-cycle and risk assessment; cost-benefit and decision analysis; valuation of ecosystem services; and critical appraisals of socio-economic valuation approaches that form the basis of policy assessments. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 541 (3) Policy Dimensions of Energy Systems
Description: Energy sources, markets, and impacts critical to energy policy, including oil, natural gas and coal markets; electricity and utilities policy; local and global environmental impacts; renewable energy; nuclear power and security; energy efficiency; technological innovation; and energy poverty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 542 (3) Science, Technology, and Public Policy
Description: Role and influence of science and technology in society, and its relationship to public policy development including: history and economics of technological change. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 543 (3) Sustainable Water Systems
Description: Valuing, managing and sustaining water systems for agriculture, industry, the built environment, recreation and ecosystems including: service delivery, government intervention and policy responses; interrelationship between water and sanitation, resource recovery, and relationships between water systems and human development. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 544 (3) Economic Foundations of Environmental Policies
Description: Environmental and natural resource economics: externalities, property rights, public goods, market failure, inter-generational trade-offs, and optimal extraction of biological and depletable resources. Environmental regulation, industrial competitiveness, and distribution of income and welfare. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 545 (3) Ecology for Policy
Description: Ecological systems for diverse policy contexts including: health, agriculture, water, resource management, tourism, spatial planning, and conservation. Innovative progress from policies and policy frameworks that better reflect ecological dynamics, and the design of appropriate policy and governance responses. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 555 (1-3) Asia Policy Practice
Description: Practice-oriented course focused on current topics affecting policy in Asia. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 560 (3) Global Governance: Frameworks and Policy Debates
Description: Policy-making at the global level, including theories and frameworks of global coordination and global governance. Global, regional, and sub-regional mechanisms. Trade, finance, climate, food regulation, developmental norms, and security. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 561 (3) Impact of Globalization on Societies
Description: Definitions of globalization and overview globalization theories; specific causes, effects, and responses of globalization in various Asian countries. Globalization in its political, social, and economic dimensions in migration and norm diffusion. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 562 (3) Resource Governance, Environment and Human Security
Description: International policy processes associated with themes of environmental security: disaster prevention; resource curse; institution building and conflict minerals and global expropriation. Issues to be considered include human rights advocacy and peacekeeping, food security and food sovereignty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 563 (3) Asia Pacific Human Migration and Social Change
Description: Key concepts and theories of migration and social change. The role of the nation state and regulatory systems considering international institutions relevant to migration as concerns Asian demography and migration; connections between Asia and the Pacific Rim. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 564 (3) Security Challenges for Asian States and People
Description: Asian state policies on security threats that impact their national and human security including: civil-military relations, intrastate conflict, transnational crime, spread of disease, and environmental and natural disasters, geo-political power shift, defence modernization, resurgent nationalism, and historical legacies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 565 (3) Nationalism, Religion, and Ethnic Conflict in Asia
Description: Ethnic and religious conflict in Asia related to historical and dialectic development of different forms of nationalism; the confluence between religion, ethnicity, and nationalist ideologies in the escalation of conflicts in different Asian societies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 566 (3) Asia Diplomacy and International Relations
Description: Comprehensive and systematic assessments and analyses of political dynamics, policy behaviors, and diplomatic interactions of Asian countries. Major diplomatic issues, cross-cutting diplomatic challenges, and opportunities facing countries in the region. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 567 (3) Human Rights and Justice
Description: Linkages between human rights, development and justice and the policy interventions which flow from them. Human rights policy including: international organizations, national actors, non-governmental organizations and communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 568 (3) Global Economic Policy
Description: Key issues, institutions and debates in global economic policymaking. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 569 (3) Global Health Policy
Description: Actors, processes and contexts shaping global health policy; politics and policy processes at the global and related levels; impact and influence of dynamics within and between different levels on health disparities and inequitable access to health services and technologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 580 (3) Internet and Global Affairs
Description: The impact of Internet on policy and global affairs structural changes to: economy with reduced transaction costs; media through new publishing forms; politics through new structures for collective action; law through limits of privacy and confidentiality; governance through e-government. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 581 (3) Behavioural Foundations for Public Policy
Description: Basic concepts in social and cognitive psychology, judgment and decision-making and behavioral economics in shaping policy formation and implementation. Application of experimental findings and concepts emanating from behavioral research to the design and implementation of policy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 582 (3) Public Engagement in Policy Decisions
Description: Public engagement in policy-making processes including: stakeholder engagement in diverse sustainability policy debates; outcomes and how they influence policy; best practices and lessons learned in North America and Europe. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 583 (3) Food Security
Description: Global food security challenges including: biophysical, economic, nutritional, socio-political, and institutional aspects. Geography of agricultural production, role of price and supply shocks, causes of malnutrition, and environmental impacts. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 584 (3) Policy Responses to Global Climate Change
Description: Climate science and impacts including: carbon management options; mitigation and energy system changes; efficiency options; 'end-of-pipe' solutions; vulnerability and adaptation to climate change; carbon economics and organization-level strategies in a carbon-constrained world. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 590 (1-6) Global Policy Project
Description: Professional team-based project that incorporates training, feedback on project proposals, possible field work, engagement with client organizations, data gathering and analysis, and a major deliverable such as a policy report. Restricted to students in the Master of Public and Global Affairs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 591 (1-9) Special Topics in Public Policy
Description: Offerings respond to current policy debates, topics of emerging interest, availability of visiting scholars, and interest in non-traditional courses incorporating practitioner expertise, interest in particular disciplinary perspectives missing from core courses and electives, and interest in specific regions or countries. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PPGA_V 592 (1.5-7.5) Professional Skills in Public Policy and Global Affairs
Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings will respond to evolving skills required for working in the field of public policy and global affairs. Restricted to students in the MPPGA program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: PUNJ_V 100 (3) Introductory Punjabi I
Description: Spoken and written Punjabi. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 100 for credit.
Title: PUNJ_V 101 (3) Introductory Punjabi II
Description: Continuation of PUNJ 100. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 101 for credit. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 100.
Title: PUNJ_V 102 (6) Introductory Punjabi
Description: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.
Title: PUNJ_V 200 (6) Intermediate Punjabi
Description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PUNJ 101, PUNJ 102.
Title: PUNJ_V 201 (3) Intermediate Punjabi I
Description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 101.
Title: PUNJ_V 202 (3) Intermediate Punjabi II
Description: Continuation of PUNJ 201. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 202 or PUNJ 200. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 201.
Title: PUNJ_V 205 (1) Introduction to the Gurmukhi Script
Description: The writing system of Punjabi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as PUNJ 200.
Title: PUNJ_V 300 (6) Advanced Punjabi
Description: Advanced grammar and conversation. Major genres of Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 301/302 or PUNJ 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of PUNJ 200, PUNJ 202.
Title: PUNJ_V 401 (3) Devotional Literature in Punjabi
Description: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.
Title: PUNJ_V 402 (3) Waris Shah's Hir
Description: A detailed study of Waris Shah's poetic narration of the story of Hir. Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.
Title: PUNJ_V 403 (3) Modern Punjabi Literature
Description: Popular and literary works in modern Punjabi, with a focus on short stories and poetry. Emphasis on reading, writing, and vocabulary development. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.
Title: PUNJ_V 404 (3) The Punjabi Novel (Advanced Punjabi)
Description: Study of the modern Punjabi novel to deepen understanding and use of Punjabi, and strengthen analysis in English and Punjabi. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.
Title: PUNJ_V 457 (3) Punjabi Theatre
Description: Punjabi-language theatre, with emphasis on Canadian forms. Reading, writing, and performance of plays; examination of history of Punjabi theatre. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.
Title: PUNJ_V 475 (3) Oral Histories in Punjabi
Description: Develops students' oral expression and listening comprehension in Punjabi through Community Based Learning. Students engage in oral history collection in the Punjabi-speaking community and develop short video or sound projects. Analytical reading and writing required. Recommended pre-requisite: PUNJ 300.
Title: RADI_V 702 (0) Clinical Investigation or Research
Description: Each resident is encouraged to complete an investigative project in each of the four years in Radiology, under the supervision of a faculty member, for possible presentation at an annual department meeting. Average 80 hours each year. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RADI_V 710 (0) Clinical Nuclear Medicine
Description: Daily discussions of the clinical applications of nuclear medicine. See PATH 730. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RADI_V 711 (0) Progress in Nuclear Medicine
Description: Weekly reviews of current literature topics in nuclear medicine. See PATH 731. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RADI_V 712 (0) Clinical Investigation/Research
Description: Participation in ongoing research projects within the division. See PATH 732. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RADI_V 713 (0) Audit in Nuclear Medicine
Description: Review of diagnostic nuclear medicine procedure, correlation with other diagnostic tests, and final patient diagnosis. Also offered as PATH 733. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 420 (4) Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
Description: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system. [2-3-0]
Title: RHSC_V 500 (2) Advanced Concepts for Rehabilitation Research
Description: Issues relevant to clinical investigations in rehabilitation. Emphasis on research design, measurement issues, selection of analytical approaches, and relevant epidemiological concepts. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 501 (3) Evidence for Practice
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 502 (3) Rehabilitation Theory
Description: The history, evolution and analysis of conceptual systems underlying practice in occupational therapy and physical therapy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 503 (3) Reasoning and Decision-Making
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 504 (3-6) Directed Studies in Rehabilitation
Description: The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 505 (3) Measurement for Assessment, Planning, and Evaluation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 506 (1-6) Current Topics in Rehabilitation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 507 (3) Developing Effective Rehabilitation Programs
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 508 (3) Cross-Cultural Issues in Rehabilitation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 509 (3) Facilitating Learning in Rehabilitation Contexts
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 510 (3) Disability: Social, Economic and Political Influence
Description: Interrelationships between disability and the social, economic and political environment, with emphasis on factors shaping experiences of health and illness. The social consequences of disability in the context of family, community and workplace. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 512 (2) Directed Studies in Pathology in Rehabilitation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 514 (3) Neuroimaging: Basic Concepts and Applications to Research and Practice
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 515 (3) Physical Activity in Health and Chronic Conditions
Description: Epidemiology, measurement, physiology, and adoption of physical activity in the prevention and treatment of chronic conditions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 516 (3) Biomechanics in Musculoskeletal Rehabilitation
Description: Biomechanical analysis of human movement as it pertains to musculoskeletal disorders. Hands-on human movement assessment. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 517 (3) Society and Human Occupation
Description: Explores society's influence on human occupation, conceptualized as all activities people do based on need, obligation, or preference. As the core construct of the discipline of occupational science and practice of occupational therapy, human occupation is examined for its impact across social, ethical and productive aspects of society. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 519 (3) Neurotrauma - from Basic to Community Research
Description: Basic, clinical, and rehabilitation research. Challenges with translational approaches and clinical issues facing people living with spinal cord and traumatic brain injury as they transition into the community. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 520 (3) Neurorehabilitation
Description: Therapeutic approaches and strategies in physical and occupational therapy for persons with motor control problems resulting from central nervous system dysfunction. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 530 (1) Research Proposal
Description: Development, appraisal and formatting of a research proposal. Emphasis on research writing and critical analysis of a variety of research proposal formats. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 537 (3) Randomized Intervention Trials in Rehabilitation
Description: Co-requisite: RHSC 500 or equivalent graduate or senior undergraduate course (300-400 level) on general quantitative and qualitative research methods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 549 (18) M.Sc. Thesis
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 581 (1.5-3) Writing to Enhance Practice
Description: The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 583 (1.5-6) Applying Research to Practice
Description: Prerequisite: RHSC 501. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 585 (3) Directed Studies
Description: Prerequisite: RHSC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 587 (3) Major Project, Part I
Description: Prerequisite: Permission of the project coordinator is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 589 (3-6) Major Project, Part II
Description: Prerequisite: RHSC 587. Permission of the project coordinator is also required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 591 (3) Leadership in Rehabilitation
Description: Leadership approaches, styles and research evidence applied to clinical rehabilitation contexts; Role and critique of emotional intelligence in effective personal leadership practices. Prerequisite: RHSC 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RHSC_V 699 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RGLA_V 371 (3) Seminar in Religion and Literature
Description: 
Title: RGLA_V 372 (3-6) Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts
Description: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.
Title: RGLA_V 471 (3) Advanced Seminar in Religion and Literature
Description: Application of critical methods to one or more major authors.
Title: RELG_V 102 (3) Introduction to Religions in Asia
Description: A survey of religious traditions of Asia, including communities, professionals, practices and beliefs of small-scale and large-scale societies. Approaches and theories drawn from the field of religious studies. Equivalency: ASIA110
Title: RELG_V 204 (6) Introduction to Asian Religions
Description: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.
Title: RELG_V 207 (3) Classical Islam
Description: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.
Title: RELG_V 208 (3) Modern Islam
Description: The history and culture, values, and socio-political movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.
Title: RELG_V 211 (3) History of Christianity II (15th C. C.E. - present)
Description: The history of Christianity from the Reformation to the present day. Provides an historical overview of Christian thought and its institutions and significant people during the rise of the Reformation in various locales of Europe and beyond (Germany, France, Great Britain, Switzerland, and Scandinavia).
Title: RELG_V 302 (3) Death and Afterlife in Western Religious Tradition
Description: A survey of traditional attitudes toward death and beliefs regarding human existence after death in Western religions.
Title: RELG_V 309 (3) Jews and Christians
Description: Aspects of Jewish-Christian relations from the beginnings of Christianity to the present day. Emphasis on the study of Christian and Jewish texts in translation.
Title: RELG_V 310 (3) Jewish Responses to Catastrophe
Description: Topics include the destruction of the Second Temple, the Crusades, the expulsions from Spain and Portugal, and the Holocaust. A study of texts in translation.
Title: RELG_V 311 (3) Jewish Literature in Translation
Description: A survey of Jewish literature in medieval and modern times.
Title: RELG_V 312 (3) Jews and Judaism in Canada
Description: The history of the Jewish community in Canada, from New France to the present. Emphasis on the relationship between immigration and religious transformation, Jewish-Christian relations, the development of community structures.
Title: RELG_V 315 (6) History of Christian Thought
Description: Selected topics with special emphasis on doctrinal change and development, orthodoxy and heresy, tradition and authority, and Church and State in the Patristic, Medieval, Reformation, and Modern periods.
Title: RELG_V 321 (3-6) Prophetic Figures in the Christian Tradition
Description: Examined in their historical context and in terms of their continuing significance. Selection will vary from year to year, but may include Augustine, Thomas Aquinas, Martin Luther, and Teresa of Avila.
Title: RELG_V 323 (6) Christianity in the Modern World
Description: The interaction between Christianity and the major intellectual, social, and cultural developments since 1648 with special attention to the expansion of Christianity and its encounter with urban industrial society.
Title: RELG_V 328 (3) Medieval Philosophy
Description: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the fourteenth century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 328 or PHIL 313. Equivalency: PHIL 313
Title: RELG_V 331 (3) Medieval Jewish History
Description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.
Title: RELG_V 332 (3) Modern Jewish History
Description: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present, with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, and social and cultural transformations.
Title: RELG_V 365 (3) Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
Description: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century C.E. in cultural, intellectual and social contexts. Equivalency: ASIA381
Title: RELG_V 366 (3) Buddhism in China
Description: History, thought and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century. Equivalency: ASIA382
Title: RELG_V 370 (6) Concepts and Methods in the Study of Religion
Description: Required of Major and Honours students in their third year. Open to others by permission of the instructor.
Title: RELG_V 385 (3) Mystical Traditions: Jewish and Christian
Description: Methodology, textual study and scholarly analysis of selected texts from these traditions.
Title: RELG_V 408 (3) Topics in Medieval Judaism
Description: The work of Maimonides and other Jewish philosophers, early developments in Jewish mysticism, the Jews as a minority culture in Islamic and Christian lands.
Title: RELG_V 409 (3) Topics in Modern Judaism
Description: The Jews in the ghetto culture, Hasidism, the Emancipation, Reform, Orthodox, and Conservative Movements.
Title: RELG_V 448 (3) Seminar in the History of the Religion of Islam
Description: A topic relevant to the study of Islam as a religion: e.g., the text and doctrines of the Qur'an; the Hadith (or Traditions) of the Prophet; Islamic Law; mysticism in Islam; the Shi'ah and the Isma'ilis. Not offered every year. Consult the departmental brochure for the topic to be offered.
Title: RELG_V 452 (6) Readings in Hindu Religious Texts
Description: Representative texts, in translation, of the Vedic, Epic, Puranic, Classical, Medieval, and Modern periods. Emphasis in the second term on texts of particular periods, movements, or sects, depending on the students' needs and interests. Those with the necessary preparation may read some texts in the original languages. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RELG_V 479 (3-6) Directed Studies
Description: Reading and, where appropriate, other research on a topic arising in the discipline, arranged by agreement between the student and the instructor. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RELG_V 485 (3) Images of Eve
Description: The story of Adam and Eve, and its influence on the role and image of women in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
Title: RELG_V 649 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 500 (3-12) Resource and Environmental Workshop
Description: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 501 (3) Development of Environmental Thought
Description: History and philosophy of Western environmental thought; changes in concepts of human nature and external nature over time; critiques of modern industrial society. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 502 (3) Master's Seminar on Resources and Environment
Description: Environment and resource management goals and issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 504 (3) Survey Design in Interdisciplinary Environmental Social Science
Description: Survey design focusing on stated and revealed environmental preferences, choices, behaviour and values. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 505 (3) Qualitative Methods in Interdisciplinary Contexts
Description: Research design, data quality, analysis, representation, ethics review, structured and unstructured interviews, field observations, survey design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 506 (3) Human Dimensions of Conservation
Description: History of wilderness and protected areas; ecological dynamics underpinning biodiversity; evaluating the success of protected areas and ecological dynamics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 507 (3) Human Technological Systems
Description: Critical analysis of harms and benefits, and anticipation of global technological innovations, as they interact with social behaviour. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 508 (3) Ecosystem Services
Description: Fostering sustainable management of ecosystem-based activities, for the competing and complementary ends of sustaining and enhancing human well-being and protecting biodiversity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 509 (3) Advanced Conservation Science
Description: Equivalency: ZOOL 509 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 510 (3) Social Ecological Systems
Description: Dynamics of environmental issues across temporal and spatial scales using disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches to integrating sociological, cultural, and ecological perspectives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 520 (3) Climate Change: Science, Technology and Sustainable Development
Description: Interdisciplinary science of climate change and its impacts; options for mitigation and adaptation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 530 (3) Knowledge, Policy and Values in Risk and Resource Management
Description: The course focuses on the role of values, science and validity of alternate knowledge systems. Included in the dialogue are the democratization of science, uncertainty, adaptive scientific practices and the values that govern management programs. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 542 (3) Integrated Assessment
Description: Basic skills for quantitative analysis including probability, validity of quantitative statements and experimental design to test hypothesis validity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 550 (3) Environmental Policy Analysis
Description: Determination of risks and values in environmental policy decisions. Equivalency: PLAN599 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 599 (12) Master's Thesis
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 602 (3) Doctoral Seminar on Resources and Environment
Description: Environment and resource management goals and issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RES_V 699 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RMST_V 100 (3) Introduction to Romance Cultures
Description: Explore the diverse cultures of France, Spain, Italy, Latin America and the Romance-speaking world from a comparative perspective.
Title: RMST_V 201 (3) Introduction to Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern
Description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Romance World as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.
Title: RMST_V 202 (3) Introduction to Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
Description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Romance World in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.
Title: RMST_V 260 (3) Introduction to the Analysis of Portuguese and Brazilian Cultures
Description: Critical analysis of different cultural genres, including music, film and visual art through the study of selected Portuguese and Brazilian texts. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 222 or RMST 260. Equivalency: PORT 222.
Title: RMST_V 270 (3) Introduction to Hispanic Cultures
Description: Cultural texts from Latin America and Spain. Examines their broad cultural and transnational impact on the Romance-speaking world of past and present.
Title: RMST_V 280 (3) Revolution!
Description: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 280 or RMST 280. Equivalency: SPAN 280.
Title: RMST_V 300 (3) History of the Romance Languages
Description: Development of the Romance language family from its origins in Latin to contemporary varieties. Emphasis on French, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish. Prerequisite: A beginners' knowledge (A1) in at least of one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.
Title: RMST_V 301 (3) Prose Fiction and Non-Fiction of the Romance World
Description: Fiction and non-fiction of the Romance-speaking world from the Middle Ages to the present day from a comparative perspective.
Title: RMST_V 302 (3) Theatre and Poetry of the Romance World
Description: Theatre and poetry of the Romance-speaking world from the Middle Ages to the present day from a comparative perspective.
Title: RMST_V 303 (3) Short Fiction in Romance Literatures
Description: A study of the genres of the novella and the short story within and across Romance cultures.
Title: RMST_V 304 (3) Afterlife of the Text: Rewritings and Adaptations
Description: How stories travel across media and across national and linguistic boundaries in the Romance-speaking world. Dialogue between different versions and inter-media translations. Questions of authorship and reception.
Title: RMST_V 305 (3) Introduction to Romance Language Cinema
Description: Overview of the history, aesthetics and characteristics of films in French, Italian, Spanish, and/or Portuguese. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 234 or RMST 305. Equivalency: RMST 234.
Title: RMST_V 306 (3) Language Contact and Multilingualism in the Romance-speaking World
Description: A sociolinguistic examination of diverse multilingual contexts that characterise the Romance-speaking world.
Title: RMST_V 307 (3) Myths, Legends and Tales in Romance Literatures and Cultures
Description: Study of foundational narratives shared by Romance literatures and cultures from a comparative perspective.
Title: RMST_V 310 (3-9) Special Topics in Romance Studies
Description: Study of Romance literatures, cultures, languages, or communities. Topics vary from section to section. Consult Department for current offerings.
Title: RMST_V 321 (3) French Literature from the Middle Ages to the Revolution
Description: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST_V 321 or MDVL_V 301. Equivalency: MDVL_V 301.
Title: RMST_V 322 (3) French Literature since the Revolution
Description: French literature through reading and analysis of translated works.
Title: RMST_V 324 (3) Quebecois Literature and Culture
Description: Study of the historical, political and cultural contexts that influenced the development of literature and culture in Quebec. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 324 or FREN 280.
Title: RMST_V 325 (3) French Cultural Identities
Description: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that weave across French history, politics, and social structures. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 325 or FREN 380.
Title: RMST_V 341 (3) Italian Literature and Culture of the Medieval and Early Modern Period
Description: A thematic approach to Italian literary works from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century considered in a broad cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 303 or RMST 341. Equivalency: ITAL 303
Title: RMST_V 342 (3) Italian Literature and Culture of the Modern and Contemporary Age
Description: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 304 or RMST 342. Equivalency: ITAL 304.
Title: RMST_V 343 (3) Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
Description: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 333, ITST 333 or RMST 343. Equivalency: ITST 333 or ITAL 333
Title: RMST_V 345 (3) Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
Description: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 345, ITST 345 or RMST 345. Equivalency: ITAL 345, ITST 345
Title: RMST_V 350 (3-9) Special Topics in Italian Studies
Description: Study of Italian literatures, cultures, languages, or communities. Topics vary from section to section. Consult Department for current offerings.
Title: RMST_V 355 (3) Italian Cinema: Neorealism
Description: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 385, ITST 385, or RMST 355. Equivalency: ITAL 385 or ITST 385
Title: RMST_V 361 (3) Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature
Description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 392 or RMST 361. Equivalency: PORT 392.
Title: RMST_V 371 (3) The Global Renaissance: Hispanic Cross-Cultural Contacts
Description: Early modern (ca. 1400-1700) literature and culture. Exploration of Spains Mediterranean, Transatlantic and Transpacific cross-cultural contacts.
Title: RMST_V 372 (3) Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature
Description: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 312 or RMST 372. Equivalency: SPAN 312.
Title: RMST_V 373 (3) Masterpieces in Hispanic Literature
Description: Literary texts from Spain and the Hispanic world. Examines their broad cultural and transnational impact on the Romance-speaking world of yesterday and today. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: RMST_V 374 (3) Mapping Gendered Spaces in Hispanic Literature and Culture
Description: Examines selected topics in gender and sexuality in diverse time periods, geographical contexts, and literary genres in Spain and Latin America.
Title: RMST_V 375 (3) The Caribbean: Frontiers of the Romance World
Description: Literature and culture from the island of Hispaniola (Haiti, Dominican Republic) and the French Caribbean from a comparative perspective.
Title: RMST_V 376 (3) Genre Adaptations in the Hispanic World
Description: Examines adaptations of works from the Hispanic World into various literary and cultural genres (including literature to film, novel to graphic novel), considering the historical and cultural context, themes, and narrative perspectives.
Title: RMST_V 390 (3) Barcelona
Description: An introduction to the city of Barcelona from a cultural studies perspective including the study of its art, literature, architecture, and social practices.
Title: RMST_V 395 (3-6) Special Topics Abroad
Description: Study of Romance language literature, history, culture, or communities in an authentic context. Topics and locations may vary. Consult Department for current offerings.
Title: RMST_V 400 (3) Romance Linguistics
Description: Vocabulary, phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and sociolinguistics of spoken and written Romance languages. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 400 or RMST 468. Prerequisite: 2nd year standing. A beginners knowledge (CFER A1) in at least one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.
Title: RMST_V 402 (3) Visions of Nature and the Environment in the Romance World
Description: History, literature and philosophy of anthropization and ecology in the Romance world. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher.
Title: RMST_V 419 (3) Studies in Romance Languages and Literature
Description: Study of a literary or cultural topic that extends beyond just one of the Romance Languages. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher.
Title: RMST_V 420 (3-9) Special Topics in Francophone Studies
Description: Study of Francophone literatures, cultures, languages, or communities. Topics vary from section to section. Consult Department for current offerings. Recommended for students in 3rd year or above. Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.
Title: RMST_V 452 (3) Italian Cinema and Its Cultural Background
Description: Films with English subtitles. Course content will vary. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 452, ITST 432 or ITAL 430. Equivalency: ITAL 430 or ITST 432.
Title: RMST_V 453 (3) Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy
Description: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works: Vita Nuova, Convivio, Monarchia, Epistles. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 453, ITST 413 or ITAL 403. Equivalency: ITST 413 or ITAL 403.
Title: RMST_V 454 (3) Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages
Description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 454, ITST 414 or ITAL 404. Equivalency: ITST 414 or ITAL 404.
Title: RMST_V 455 (3) Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance
Description: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 455, ITST 415 or ITAL 405. Equivalency: ITAL 405 or ITST 415
Title: RMST_V 456 (3) Classics of Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
Description: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 416 or ITAL 406 or RMST 456.
Title: RMST_V 457 (3) Classics of Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
Description: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 417 or ITAL 407 or RMST 457. Equivalency: ITST 417 or ITAL 407
Title: RMST_V 458 (3) Topics in Nineteenth-century Italian Literature and Culture
Description: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 418 or ITAL 408 or RMST 458. Equivalency: ITST 418 or ITAL 408
Title: RMST_V 459 (3) Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture
Description: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 459, ITST 419 or ITAL 409. Recommended pre-requisite: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: ITST 419 or ITAL 409.
Title: RMST_V 460 (3) Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture
Description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 405 or RMST 460. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: PORT 405.
Title: RMST_V 470 (3-9) Special Topics in Hispanic Studies
Description: Study of Hispanic literatures, cultures, languages, or communities. Topics vary from section to section. Consult Department for current offerings. Recommended for students in 3rd year or above. Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.

Title: RUSS_V 100 (6) First-Year Russian
Description: Introduction to contemporary Russian Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.
Title: RUSS_V 101 (3) Basic Russian I
Description: Introduction to contemporary Russian. Oral practice, grammar, reading, and writing.
Title: RUSS_V 102 (3) Basic Russian II
Description: Continuation of RUSS 101.
Title: RUSS_V 112 (3) Russian for Singers
Description: Study of Russian language and culture for opera students.
Title: RUSS_V 200 (6) Second-Year Russian
Description: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 200 or both of RUSS 201 and RUSS 202. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 100, RUSS 102.
Title: RUSS_V 201 (3) Second-Year Russian I
Description: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 201 or RUSS 200. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 100, RUSS 102.
Title: RUSS_V 202 (3) Second-Year Russian II
Description: A continuation of RUSS 201. Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 202 or RUSS 200. Recommended pre-requisite: RUSS 201.
Title: RUSS_V 206 (3) Nineteenth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
Description: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.
Title: RUSS_V 207 (3) Twentieth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
Description: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.
Title: RUSS_V 215 (3) Russian Practice
Description: Emphasis on oral practice and reading. It is recommended that this course be taken concurrently with one of the following: RUSS 200, RUSS 201, RUSS 202. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 100, RUSS 102.
Title: RUSS_V 300 (6) Third-Year Russian
Description: Intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 200, RUSS 202.
Title: RUSS_V 301 (3) Third-Year Russian I
Description: Advanced intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 301 or 300. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 200, RUSS 202.
Title: RUSS_V 302 (3) Third -Year Russian II
Description: Advanced intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 302 or RUSS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: RUSS 301.
Title: RUSS_V 303 (3-6) Topics in Russian Culture (in English)
Description: Features of Russian culture with an emphasis on historical and social contexts. Specific course content will vary. Consult CENES for this year's offerings at https://cenes.ubc.ca/undergraduate/slavic-studies/russian-minor/
Title: RUSS_V 305 (3) Readings in Russian Literary Texts
Description: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21st-century sources. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 200, RUSS 202.
Title: RUSS_V 306 (3-6) Russian Literature in Translation
Description: A comprehensive historical and critical presentation with emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
Title: RUSS_V 315 (3) Advanced Russian Practice
Description: Continuation of RUSS 215. May be taken concurrently with RUSS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: RUSS 215.
Title: RUSS_V 316 (3) Russian through Film (in Russian)
Description: Conversation and composition using Russian film. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 200, RUSS 202.
Title: RUSS_V 321 (3-6) Imagining Location in Russian Literature (in English)
Description: Russian literature and film, focused around a particular geographical and cultural location.
Title: RUSS_V 323 (3-6) Fantastic Worlds in Russian Fiction (in English)
Description: Russian genre fiction and film (science fiction, fantasy and gothic).
Title: RUSS_V 400 (3-6) Fourth-Year Russian
Description: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition. Recommended pre-requisites: one of RUSS 300, RUSS 302.
Title: RUSS_V 401 (6) Russian for Reading Knowledge
Description: Russian for Reading Knowledge This course provides a reading knowledge of Russian, sufficient to enable students to understand scientific and scholarly material. Basic grammar and practice in the translation into English of texts in the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities. Intended primarily for upper-year and graduate students.
Title: RUSS_V 407 (3-6) Studies in Russian Poetry
Description: For further details see Department. Recommended pre-requisite: RUSS 300.
Title: RUSS_V 408 (3-6) Studies in Russian Prose Before 1917
Description: See Department for further details. Recommended pre-requisite: RUSS 300.
Title: RUSS_V 409 (3-6) Contemporary Russian Literature after 1917
Description: See Department for further details. Recommended pre-requisite: RUSS 300.
Title: RUSS_V 410 (3-6) Women in Russian Literature and Culture
Description: Analysis of translated texts by and concerning women from folklore to contemporary society.
