Title: SANS_V 300 (6) Introductory Sanskrit
Description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.
Title: SANS_V 301 (3) Introductory Sanskrit I
Description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.
Title: SANS_V 302 (3) Introductory Sanskrit II
Description: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 301.
Title: SANS_V 400 (6) Intermediate Sanskrit
Description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.
Title: SANS_V 401 (3) Intermediate Sanskrit I
Description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.
Title: SANS_V 402 (3) Intermediate Sanskrit II
Description: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 401.
Title: SANS_V 450 (6-18) Further Readings in Sanskrit
Description: Study of selected texts belonging to a particular period (e.g., Vedic) or representing a specific branch of kavya (poetic literature) or sastra (technical-philosophical literature). Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 200, SANS 202, SANS 400, SANS 402.
Title: SPHA_V 501 (1.5) Basic Finance
Description: Fundamental concepts of asset pricing and corporate finance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 502 (1.5) Managerial Accounting
Description: Development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports. Same as BAAC 550; credit will not be given for both. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 503 (1.5) Financial Accounting
Description: Financial accounting concepts as they relate to health care administration, including the preparation of external financial reports and financial statement and analysis. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 510 (1.5) Canadian Health Policy and the Healthcare System
Description: Analysis of topical Canadian health policy issues including an historical overview of the health care system, health care funding, public / private financing, health care personnel and pharmaceutical policy challenges. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 511 (1.5) Government, Business and Health Care Policy
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 512 (1.5) Indigenous Health and Cultural Safety
Description: Core concepts of Indigenous-specific racism and human rights, cultural safety and how this relates to the practice of health administrators. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 521 (1.5) Organizational Behavior
Description: The effects of individual and group behaviour on organizational processes and outcomes. The organization as an actor and how it behaves in different types of environments. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 522 (1.5) Strategic Human Resources Management
Description: Aligning the management of human resources with organizational strategy. Best practices in HR management, as well as the role of health care leaders in effectiveness and efficiency. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 531 (1.5) Economic Evaluation
Description: Maximizing health benefits from health care budgets. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 532 (1.5) Health Economics
Description: Economic strengths and weaknesses of current arrangements, and the prospects and objectives of various proposals for reform. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 533 (1.5) Health Care Priority Setting
Description: Application of priority setting and resource allocation methods to improve health from the perspective of the policy maker, health professional, and patient. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 542 (1.5) Operations and Logistics
Description: The application of management tools and principles to production and allocation problems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 543 (1.5) Information Technology for Management
Description: The role of IT in health care management, the importance of effective IT in a health care setting, and the strategic uses of IT. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 544 (1.5) Health Information Systems
Description: Information systems in planning and management of health care services provided through single-purpose units, comprehensive clinics and hospitals. Emphasis on computerized systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 551 (1.5) Design and Measurement 1
Description: Basic concepts and methods in Epidemiology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 552 (1.5) Design and Measurement 2
Description: Clinical Epidemiology, trials and the evaluation of diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 553 (1.5) Program Planning and Evaluation
Description: Basic concepts and principles underlying program planning and evaluation in health services. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 554 (1.5) Application of Statistics in Management
Description: Data analysis and statistical inference. Applications in assessment of the legitimacy and significance of reports. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 555 (1.5) Biostatistics
Description: Data collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis. Examples primarily from health sciences. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 556 (1.5) Social Determinants of Health
Description: Foundations of population health. An overview of research on determinants of health, with an emphasis on the social determinants of health. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 557 (1.5) Quality of Health Care
Description: Current concepts, methods, and applications in health care quality assessment and improvement. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 561 (1.5) Strategic Management
Description: Management of multi-faceted organizations; weighting functions, understanding industry and organization-specific effects. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 562 (1.5) Health Care Law
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 563 (1.5) Ethics and Ethical Decision Making in Health Care
Description: Ethical dilemmas in the health care setting. Understanding how Ethical features of the system may contribute to or perpetuate some of these problems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 564 (1.5) Leadership and Management Skills
Description: A comprehensive understanding of what it takes to be a credible leader in the health economy. Concepts of leadership through a number of lenses and perspectives, using case studies, group activities and individual assignments. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 580 (1.5) Selected Topics
Description: Current and emerging trends and issues. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 581 (1.5-3) Directed Studies
Description: Opportunity to focus on a selected topic under faculty supervision. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPHA_V 590 (1.5-6) Research Project
Description: Completion of a bounded project within a health agency and under individual faculty supervision. Honours/Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 200 (3) Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
Description: The idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. [3-0-0]
Title: SPPH_V 300 (3) Working in Global Health
Description: Planning/preparing for work in global health, with attention to health inequities and determinants internationally and domestically, the pursuit of partnerships to address this, power imbalances and ethical principles for carrying out this work. Health Science background not essential.
Title: SPPH_V 301 (3) Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
Description: The idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. [3-0-0]
Title: SPPH_V 302 (3) Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
Description: Basic literacy in health informatics. Innovative approaches to healthcare implementation, access to care, and data utilization.
Title: SPPH_V 303 (3) Environmental Impacts on Human Health
Description: Harmful environmental exposures in water, air, food; aspects of environment that are beneficial for health; environmental justice; emerging environmental health threats; how epidemiology and risk assessment inform public health policy and practice.
Title: SPPH_V 304 (3) Canadian Health Care Policy
Description: Features of the Canadian health care system, stages in the evolution of Medicare, and how institutions, interests, and ideas shape health care policies.
Title: SPPH_V 381 (1.5-3) Selected Topics
Description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.
Title: SPPH_V 401 (3) Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
Description: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control. Equivalency: PATH 477
Title: SPPH_V 404 (3) Indigenous Health: Historical Impacts and Contemporary Approaches
Description: This course covers an epistemological approach that considers the social determinants of health and Indigenous spiritual-environmental and cultural perspectives and approaches to health and wellness.
Title: SPPH_V 406 (3) Aging from an Interdisciplinary Perspective
Description: Population and Public Health issues associated with aging.
Title: SPPH_V 408 (6) Topics in Aboriginal Health: Community-based Learning Experience
Description: In-depth cultural and interprofessional learning experience that enables students to live and study in BC First Nations communities while learning about health, wellness, and community strengths from a local perspective.
Title: SPPH_V 409 (3) International Indigenous Experiences of Colonization
Description: Interprofessional, comparative inquiry of Indigenous experiences of global colonization and the manifestations of that experience in the contemporary socio-cultural environment. Informed and guided by Indigenous knowledge and drawing upon a range of disciplines.
Title: SPPH_V 410 (3) Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
Description: Improving public health by developing the skills to design and deliver pragmatic, effective health behavior change interventions.
Title: SPPH_V 411 (3) Violence Across the Lifespan
Description: Overview of violence across the lifespan. Epidemiology, dynamics, health effects, intervention and prevention.
Title: SPPH_V 481 (1-6) Special Topics in Population and Public Health
Description: Selected topics will vary. Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.
Title: SPPH_V 500 (3) Analytical Methods in Epidemiological Research
Description: Basic epidemiological designs as a framework for commonly used biostatistical techniques such as the Mantel-Haenszel, chi-squared, linear and logistic regression, and survival analysis. Computer packages will be available for computation of assignments. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 567, SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 501 (3) Analysis of Longitudinal Data from Epidemiological Studies
Description: To explore and compare methods of analyzing continuous and categorical longitudinal data. The issues of missing data and errors in measurement/misclassification will be covered in depth. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 567. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 502 (3) Epidemiological Methods 1
Description: Sources and uses of epidemiologic data for health services planning and administration including methods of data collection and study design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 503 (3) Epidemiological Methods 2
Description: Critical thinking in epidemiology; principles and methods of study design; context for epidemiological investigations of human health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 504 (3) Application of Epidemiological Methods
Description: This second level course will teach research trainees to apply methods taught in prior courses towards the development of a fundable research protocol and the analysis and interpretation of real epidemiologic data. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 505 (3) Scientific Basis for Epidemiological Thinking
Description: The course will provide a framework for students to use epidemiological and other scientific evidence to make decisions about causation and to recommend policy actions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 506 (3) Quantitative Research Methods
Description: Major quantitative research designs, measurement reliability and validity, common data sources used, internal and external validity, research proposals, and peer review. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 506 or SPPH 548. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 507 (1.5) M.Sc. Research Seminar
Description: SPPH 507 in conjunction with SPPH 607 is a required course for students in the M.Sc. program. Students present and discuss their research and other topics of interest. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 508 (6) M.P.H. Practicum
Description: Applied epidemiology and biostatistics in a field setting. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 509 (3) Genetic Epidemiology
Description: Human genetics and genomics, behavioural, social, and environmental factors in modifying or influencing genetics in the manifestation of disease. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 510 (3) Survey Methods in Health Measurement
Description: Concepts and techniques of measurement in epidemiological research. Topics covered include validity, reliability and misclassification, scale design and the construction of questionnaires and indices for both health outcomes and exposures. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 400, SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 511 (3) Cancer Control and Epidemiology
Description: Collection and analysis of epidemiological data on cancer; genetic, occupational, and other risk factors; analytic techniques; cancer control, prevention, screening, early detection, and policy issues. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or equivalent. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 512 (3) The Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
Description: Ethical considerations, intention-to-treat versus efficacy trials, principles of sampling and exclusion, methods of allocation and techniques of randomization, parallel versus cross over design, monitoring treatment outcomes, adverse effects, stopping rules, analytic techniques and data interpretation, and logistical issues in the management of clinical trials. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 502, SPPH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 513 (3) Clinical Epidemiology
Description: Principles and methods of epidemiology are applied to clinical problems. Evaluation and design of laboratory and clinical tests and of therapeutic interventions. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 514 (3) Decision Analysis in Health Care
Description: Methods and application of decision analysis to improve health from the perspective of the policy maker, health professional, and patient. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 515 (3) Surveillance and Monitoring in Public Health
Description: Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 516 (3) Methods for Systematic Reviews in Health Research
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 517 (3) Clinical Research methods for Surgical Procedures
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 518 (3) Mathematical Modelling of Communicable Diseases
Description: Application of mathematical models in understanding communicable disease dynamics and control; interpretation of model outcomes; modelling methods and their applications. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 519 (3) Qualitative Methods in Health Research Design
Description: Purposes, context, procedures, and relationships within qualitative health research and methologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 520 (3) Control of Communicable Disease
Description: Epidemiology of viral, bacterial and parasitic infections with emphasis on the control of these infections in human populations. Immunization programs will be stressed. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 521 (3) Statistics for Health Research
Description: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and nonparametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 522 (3) Topics in Environmental Health
Description: Role of air, water, food and solid waste as sources of human health risks; global environmental health issues; sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 523 (3) Global Health and Human Security
Description: Global threats to human health stemming from conflict, poverty, and environmental degradation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 524 (3) Core Biological Concepts of Public Health Practice
Description: Cell biology, microbiology, molecular science, genetics, physiology, and evolution. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 525 (3) Issues and Concepts in Public Health
Description: History of public health research and practice; occupational and environmental health; health services and systems; social and lifecourse determinants of health; and population health and emerging trends. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 526 (3) Leadership in Public Health
Description: Organizational structure; engaging others in an organization; inter-organizational networking; building coalitions; identification of opportunities to bring change to organizations through knowledge development, management, synthesis, and implementation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 527 (3) Social Determinants of Health
Description: Foundational thinking giving rise to the concept of population health. Overview of the current state of research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 528 (3) Rural and Remote Health
Description: Issues and solutions to delivery of health services to underserved rural populations. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502.. Corequisite: SPPH 500 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 529 (0) Major Essay
Description: Required for all M.H.Sc. students. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 530 (3) Epidemiology of Occupational and Environmental Health
Description: Design and analysis of etiologic research in occupational health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 531 (3) Health Care Systems Analysis
Description: Theory, concepts, measurement, and practical skills using administrative data for analysis of health care systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 532 (3) Environmental Health Risk Assessment and Communication
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 533 (3) Toxicology and Public Health
Description: Mechanism of action of commonly encountered occupational toxic agents; relevance of laboratory and epidemiological evidence. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 534 (3) Occupational Health and Illness Processes
Description: Occupational diseases; research, historical perspectives, and surveillance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 535 (3) Principles of Occupational and Environmental Hygiene
Description: Scientific basis for the recognition, evaluation, and control of chemical, physical, and biological, exposures; standard setting; exposure monitoring methods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 536 (3) Aboriginal People and Public Health: Ethics, Policy, and Practice
Description: Experience of colonization; Indian Act; the histories and intergenerational impact of the residential school; child-welfare systems; communicable disease prevention; the challenge of ethical public health practice; and traditional healing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 537 (3) Perinatal Epidemiology
Description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. Corequisite: SPPH 500 Equivalency: OBST 507 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 538 (3) Application of Ethical Theories in the Practice of Public Health
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 539 (3) Epidemiology of Aging and Chronic Diseases
Description: Biology of aging, epidemiology of cardiovascular disease, neoplasms, osteoporosis and fractures, psychosocial factors and health in old age, dementias, functional status, and prevention of disease. Prerequisite: SPPH 502, SPPH 524 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 540 (3) Program Planning and Evaluation
Description: Examines the concept of evaluation in health services and how various methodological approaches can be used in evaluative studies. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 541 (3) Economic Evaluation
Description: Economic evaluation of health service interventions and programs, with emphasis on methods and components of program costing. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 542 (3) Canadian Health Policy
Description: Analysis of the evolution and structure of the Canadian health care system. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 543 (3) Health Technology Assessment for Health Policy
Description: This course is an advanced program evaluation course. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 544 (3) Socal Determinants of Health Across the Life Course
Description: The social determinants of health have profound impacts on inequities across the life course, as do population-level interventions. Builds on SPPH 527, with an emphasis on life course perspectives and vulnerable populations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 545 (3) Community Health Promotion
Description: Practice and community-based (participatory) research related to health promotion, including its historical and philosophical roots. Application of social and behavioural theories to participatory research and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of community health promotion initiatives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 546 (3) Introduction to Health Economics
Description: Broad understanding of the health system and health system change from an economics perspective, with a focus on delivery, organization, and financing of healthcare. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 547 (3) Health Care Priority Setting
Description: Resource allocation, economics and ethics based approaches for decision making, uptake of evidence to inform resource use in health care. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 548 (3) Knowledge to Action in Population Health
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 549 (3) Advanced Economic Evaluation in Health Care
Description: Economic evaluation of health technologies, considering, in detail, the policy context for the use of economic evaluation. Prerequisite: SPPH 541. Or equivalent training. Equivalency: PHAR 560. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 550 (3) Public Health Approaches to Substance Use and Addictions
Description: Critical examination of strategies regarding addictive behaviours, substance use and related problems, in the context of a multi-disciplinary approach. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 551 (3) Pharmacoepidemiology
Description: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 551 or PHAR 561. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 552 (3) Science and Risk Communication for Public Health
Description: Theory and practice of risk communication in public health, basic principles underlying effective science communication with peers, the media, and the public. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 553 (3) Foundations of Public Health Computing
Description: Data gathering, cleaning, analysis, and visualization to produce key results using statistical software. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 554 (3) Addiction and Mental Health
Description: Severe addiction and mental illness and the systemic context in which they occur. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 555 (3) Principles and Practices of Injury Prevention
Description: Injury epidemiology; surveillance; development, implementation, and evaluation techniques of preventive strategies; determinants of health; social marketing; injury policy; evidence-based prevention strategies; utilization of injury datasets. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 559 (3) Major Essay
Description: Required for Master of Health Administration (M.H.A.) non-thesis program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 562 (3) Chemical and Biological Hazard Measurement
Description: Industrial hygiene and environmental exposure monitoring, methods, and instrumentation, and theory. Laboratories demonstrate workplace sampling and analysis techniques. [2-3] Prerequisite: SPPH 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 563 (3) Technical Aspects of Occupational Hygiene Hazard Controls
Description: Industrial ventilation, heating and air conditioning systems, respiratory protection, chemical protective clothing. Prerequisite: SPPH 535. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 564 (3) Advanced Topics in Occupational and Environmental Health
Description: Recommended: SPPH 567 or an equivalent statistics or quantitative course is recommended. Prerequisite: All of SPPH 502, SPPH 535. Corequisite: SPPH 522. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 565 (3) Ergonomics
Description: Human factors in workplace design, anthropometry, work physiology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 566 (3) Occupational Hygiene Practice
Description: Application of occupational hygiene principles using field investigations, critical appraisal of results, and communication with labour and management. [2-3] Prerequisite: SPPH 562. Corequisite: SPPH 563. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 567 (3) Quantitative Methods for the Assessment and Analysis of Exposure Data
Description: Determinants of exposure, sampling strategies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 568 (3) Occupational Safety Programs and Systems
Description: Safety management; systems analysis; accident investigation; collection of accident data; fault trees; total loss control. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 569 (3) Industrial and Environmental Acoustics and Vibration
Description: Fundamentals of acoustics and vibrations, physiologic effects, measurement, instrumentation, interpretation of data, industrial standards, and control. For students in Occupational and Environmental Hygiene; other graduate students may enrol with permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 570 (6) Current Issues in Public Health Practice
Description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 571 (3) Public Health, Transportation, and the Built Environment
Description: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571. Equivalency: PLAN579 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 576 (1.5) Introduction to Indigenous Health Research Ethics
Description: Principles and regulatory requirements related to conducting health research with Indigenous communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 577 (1.5) Environmental Health and Indigenous Communities
Description: Environmental risk factors faced by Indigenous communities in land, air and water. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 578 (1.5) Social Determinants of Indigenous Health
Description: Survey of impacts of land and resources, housing, education, criminal justice systems, child apprehension and other determinants on the health of Indigenous peoples in Canada. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 579 (1.5) Collecting, Analyzing and Using Public Health Data in Indigenous Communities
Description: Applied biostatistics, epidemiology and data management addressing public health priorities and clinical research in Indigenous communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 580 (3-6) Directed Studies
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 581 (1.5-3) Selected Topics
Description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 586 (1.5) Indigenous Health Policy in Canada
Description: Indigenous health policy and history in Canada through four substantive areas: economics and financing; need and demand; ethics, rights and law; quality and effectiveness. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 587 (1.5) Mental Health Care and Delivery in Indigenous Communities
Description: Approaches to mental health and resilience concepts and strength based interventions with Indigenous communities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 588 (1.5) Introduction to Quantitative and Qualitative Research Methods in Indigenous Health Research
Description: Qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods research as applied to Indigenous public health priorities. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 589 (1.5) Interdisciplinary Approach to Understanding the Health of Indigenous Peoples
Description: Indigenous health through core public health disciplines and interdisciplinary approaches. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 598 (6) Occupational and Environmental Hygiene Project
Description: Applied project on approved topic based on practicum: requires a written and oral report. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 599 (12) M.Sc. Thesis
Description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 604 (3) Application of Advanced Epidemiological Methods
Description: Statistical approaches for confounding, missingness, and complex surveys, the development of analysis plans, the analysis and interpretation of real-world epidemiologic data, and the communication of findings. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502; and one of SPPH 503, SPPH 506, SPPH 519, SPPH 530. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 607 (1.5) Ph.D. Research Seminar
Description: Required course in Ph.D. program. Topics of current interest will be presented and discussed by students and various faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 621 (3) Approaches to Enquiry in Population and Public Health
Description: Research approaches in the area of population and public health; focus on developing research questions and the centrality of research questions in conducting research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 681 (1.5-3) Selected Topics
Description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 699 (0) Doctoral Dissertation
Description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 710 (0) Current Issues in Public Health Practice
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 711 (0) Field Experience
Description: A series of visits to facilities and organizations related to Community Medicine Practice. Directed by Faculty. At least four hours per month. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 712 (0) Supervised Work
Description: A weekly review by Faculty of the work carried out by the resident with discussion on the objectives, planning, method of operation and outcome. Two hours per week. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 713 (0) Community Health Tutorials
Description: Topics of Public Health interest presented throughout the year by Faculty and guest lecturers. Two hours per month. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 714 (0) Community Medicine Seminars
Description: Selected topics of current interest in Community Medicine Practice or in its basic sciences. Presented by residents and discussed with Faculty and invited guests. Three hours per month. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 715 (0) Journal Seminars
Description: A monthly two-hour seminar on selected journal articles of Community Medicine interest are presented by the residents and discussed with Faculty and invited guests. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 716 (0) Research in Community Medicine or its Basic Sciences by a Resident
Description: Up to two days per week. Supervised by Faculty. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 717 (0) Introduction to Occupational Medicine Practice
Description: An introductory survey to Occupational Medicine practice. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SPPH_V 718 (0) Fundamentals of Clinical Epidemiology
Description: Seminar series covering critical appraisal of the medical literature and basic research methods for residents in any post-graduate training program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 001 (28) Science One
Description: An innovative first-year multi-disciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines. See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca) for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001. [12-6-4;12-6-4] Prerequisite: All of: CALC 12, ENGL 12, and Pre-calculus 12; two of: CHEM 12, PHYS 12, High School Biology (either BIOL 11 or BIOL 12). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 010 (0) Science One A
Description: Block registration marker for the biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics components of the Science One program. Restricted to students in the Science One program. [12-6-4] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12; and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.
Title: SCIE_V 100 (1) First-Year Focus Seminar
Description: Seminar for First-Year Focus option focused on discipline-specific learning strategies for academic success and community and scholarly engagement. This course is restricted to first-year students in the First-Year Focus option. Pass/Fail [1*-0-1*] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 113 (3) First-Year Seminar in Science
Description: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts. Enrolment limited to students in the B. Sc. program in Science. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 120 (1) Topics in Sustainability Science
Description: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses. [1-0-0] Corequisite: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.
Title: SCIE_V 300 (3) Communicating Science
Description: Effective communication and presentation skills in science. [1-0-3] Corequisite: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 241. and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.
Title: SCIE_V 320 (3) Socio-Ecological Systems Research
Description: Research design and methods for socio-ecological systems research. Students work directly with faculty mentors to conduct research on contemporary topics such as climate resilience, food security, and environmental sustainability. [1.5-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing and instructor's permission
Title: SCIE_V 400 (3) Discipline-based Education Research Methodology
Description: Overview of methodological approaches to education research in disciplines having natural, physical, and life-science foundations. Prerequisite: Third-year standing and permission of the instructor. Equivalency: SCIE500
Title: SCIE_V 420 (3) Sustainability for Community and the World
Description: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, EOSC 345, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW 386, LFS 250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, PSYC 421, SCIE 120, SCIE 320. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Title: SCIE_V 500 (3) Discipline-based Education Research Methodology
Description: Overview of methodological approaches to education research in disciplines having natural, physical, and life-science foundations. Equivalency: SCIE 400 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 596 (3) Co-operative Work Placement I
Description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 597 (3) Co-operative Work Placement II
Description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Prerequisite: SCIE 596. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 598 (3) Co-operative Work Placement III
Description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Prerequisite: SCIE 597 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SCIE_V 599 (3) Co-operative Work Placement IV
Description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Prerequisite: SCIE 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: STS_V 501 (3) Proseminar in Science and Technology Studies
Description: Classic work in the history, philosophy, rhetoric, and sociology of science, and the development of a unified science and technology studies. Required for all students in the STS Program. This course is co-taught. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: STS_V 502 (3) Core Seminar in Science and Technology Studies
Description: Thematizes the relations of historical, philosophical, literary, rhetorical, sociological, and anthropological approaches to science and technology. Recommended pre-requisite: STS 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: STS_V 597 (3) Master's Colloquium in Science and Technology Studies
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: STS_V 598 (3-6) Doctoral Colloquium in Science and Technology Studies
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: STS_V 599 (12) Master's Thesis
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SLAV_V 105 (6) Introduction to Russian and Slavic Culture
Description: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present.
Title: SLAV_V 307 (3-6) Literature and Film in Eastern Europe
Description: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.
Title: SGES_V 501 (6) Integration Project
Description: Design, analysis, and implementation of technology to create a bench-scale smart grid energy system. Assessment of technology based on sustainability, market, policy and regulatory considerations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SGES_V 502 (3) Renewable and Efficient Electric Power Systems
Description: Electricity infrastructure, fundamentals of electric power, solar photovoltaic systems, wind electric conversion systems, other renewable energy systems, grid integration of renewables, smart grid, distributed energy resources, electricity storage. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SGES_V 503 (2) Topics in Power and Energy
Description: Current topics in smart grid systems and technologies in the context of sustainability, market, policy and regulation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SGES_V 531 (3) Smart Grid Communication Systems
Description: Review of probability theory, signals and noise, spectral analysis; information theory and applications; detection and estimation of signals in the presence of noise; performance calculations of modulation systems; digital communication techniques. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 531 or ELEC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SGES_V 550 (2) Power Electronic Devices
Description: New devices and applications in power electronics with applications to smart grid systems. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 550 or EECE 550. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SGES_V 592 (2) Architecture for Learning Systems
Description: Learning in neural networks, error backpropagation, simulated annealing, content addressable memories. Data representation topics. Implementation challenges in real world scale problems. Architectures for function approximation in Reinforcement Learning. Comparison with conventional artificial intelligence: history and emerging trends. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 592 or EECE 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 200 (3) Introduction to Social Welfare
Description: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.
Title: SOWK_V 201 (3) Introduction to Social Work Practice
Description: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems. Prerequisite: SOWK200
Title: SOWK_V 305 (3-9) Topics in Social Work Practice I
Description: Examinations of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying various topics in generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program
Title: SOWK_V 310 (3-6) Interviewing Skills
Description: Communication theory and interviewing skills and their application to the Social Work interview. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.
Title: SOWK_V 315 (6) Practicum I
Description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail. Corequisite: SOWK 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 316 (3) Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
Description: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.
Title: SOWK_V 325 (3) Indigenous Peoples and Critical Social Work Analysis
Description: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.
Title: SOWK_V 335 (3-6) Topics in Social Analysis for Social Work Practice
Description: Theoretical considerations of relevance to social work practice.
Title: SOWK_V 337 (3) Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
Description: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.
Title: SOWK_V 400 (3) Canadian Social Policy
Description: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.
Title: SOWK_V 405 (3) Social Work Practice II
Description: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.
Title: SOWK_V 415 (6) Practicum II
Description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 416 (3) Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
Description: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.
Title: SOWK_V 420 (3) Introduction to Social Work Research
Description: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 430 (3-6) Special Studies in Social Work
Description: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.
Title: SOWK_V 440 (3-12) Integrative Seminars in Social Work
Description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.
Title: SOWK_V 441 (3) Social Context of Child Development
Description: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 or FMST 441. Equivalency: FMST 441
Title: SOWK_V 442 (3) Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
Description: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.
Title: SOWK_V 450 (3) Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
Description: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in SOWK. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 451 (3) Health Care Team Development
Description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400. Equivalency: IHHS 400.
Title: SOWK_V 452 (6) HIV Prevention and Care
Description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 453 (3) Disability and Justice
Description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.
Title: SOWK_V 454 (3) Interdisciplinary Practice with Children and Families
Description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.
Title: SOWK_V 455 (6) Palliative Care
Description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.
Title: SOWK_V 456 (1-6) Special Topics in Collaborative Healthcare
Description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares students to practice patient-centred interprofessional collaboration in a specific area of healthcare. Offered as IHHS 480 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 456 or IHHS 480.
Title: SOWK_V 501 (3) Advanced Canadian Social Policy
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 502 (6) Social Work Practice
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 503 (3) Communication Skills in Social Work Practice
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOWK_V 504 (3-6) Feminism and Social Work Praxis
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: SOWK_V 601 (3) Social Work Doctoral Seminar

Title: SOWK_V 621 (3) Social Theory, Ideology and Ethics
Description: Critical analysis of major social theories, differentiating competing approaches to understanding human behaviour; social theory, social ideology, and social ethics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: SOWK_V 699 (0) Doctoral Dissertation

Title: SOCI_V 100 (6) Introduction to Sociology
Description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 101 (3) Social Interaction and Culture
Description: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.
Title: SOCI_V 102 (3) Inequality and Social Change
Description: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.
Title: SOCI_V 200 (3) Sociology of Family
Description: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.
Title: SOCI_V 201 (3) Ethnicity
Description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.
Title: SOCI_V 204 (3) Global Population Dynamics
Description: Core processes that influence world population patterns and trends.
Title: SOCI_V 210 (3) Canadian Social Structure
Description: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.
Title: SOCI_V 217 (3) Research Methods
Description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
Title: SOCI_V 220 (3) Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
Description: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.
Title: SOCI_V 224 (3) Sociology of Personal Life
Description: A sociological examination of everyday life exploring the social in the personal.
Title: SOCI_V 230 (3) Shopping, Society, and Sustainability
Description: Major theories of consumer society, evaluating impacts of shopping on human and non-human environments and popular solutions to these impacts.
Title: SOCI_V 240 (3) Introduction to Social Interaction
Description: Research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour.
Title: SOCI_V 250 (3) Crime and Society
Description: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies.
Title: SOCI_V 260 (3) Work and Society
Description: Social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work, labour force dynamics, and technological change.
Title: SOCI_V 270 (3) Sociology of Creativity
Description: The application of sociological concepts to the examination of creative processes.
Title: SOCI_V 280 (3) Data and Society
Description: Impacts of changing information and communication technologies on societies and social interactions.
Title: SOCI_V 284 (3) Health and Society
Description: An introduction to health and illness through a sociological lens. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 285 (3) Citizenship and Identity
Description: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).
Title: SOCI_V 290 (3) Global Pandemics
Description: Global pandemics in relation to social inequality, social interaction and social institutions.
Title: SOCI_V 301 (3) Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
Description: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 302 (3) Ethnic and Racial Inequality
Description: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 303 (3) Sociology of Migration
Description: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 310 (3) Canadian Society
Description: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 312 (3) Gender Relations
Description: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 314 (3) Sociology of Masculinity
Description: How masculinity differs across social contexts and time periods. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 320 (3) Diversity in Family Forms
Description: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
Title: SOCI_V 324 (3) Sociology of the Life Course
Description: Individuals and families through the life course. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
Title: SOCI_V 328 (3) Social Statistics I
Description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List (https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult�) before registering. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 342 (3) Consumers and Consumption
Description: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 344 (3) Sociology of Aging
Description: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: SOCI 444.
Title: SOCI_V 352 (3) Work and Inequality
Description: The meaning of work and leisure, properties of work organization, the division of labour, and the relation of work and social inequality. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 354 (3) Community Studies
Description: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 360 (3) Sociology and Natural Resources
Description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 361 (3) Social Inequality
Description: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 364 (3) Built Environments
Description: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 369 (3) Sociology of Sexualities
Description: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
Title: SOCI_V 370 (6) Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
Description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 371 (3) Classical Traditions in Theory
Description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 372 (3) Contemporary Directions in Theory
Description: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 380 (3) Sociological Methods: Survey Research
Description: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 217.
Title: SOCI_V 381 (3) Sociological Methods: Experimental Research
Description: Research strategies associated with the implementation of experimental methods in sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.
Title: SOCI_V 382 (3) Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
Description: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.
Title: SOCI_V 383 (3) Sociological Methods: Historical Research
Description: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.
Title: SOCI_V 384 (3) Sociology of Health and Illness
Description: Classic and contemporary sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 387 (3) Drugs and Society
Description: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance use from Canadian and international perspectives. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 410 (3-12) Selected Topics in Canadian Society
Description: Selected areas of study relating to Canadian society such as BC Studies; French Canada's demographic problems; rural communities; social welfare and community programs in Canada. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 414 (3) Feminist Theory
Description: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 415 (3-6) Theories of Family and Kinship
Description: Theoretical approaches to the study of the family and family forms. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.
Title: SOCI_V 416 (3-12) Selected Topics in Sociological Theory
Description: An in-depth examination of selected sociological theories. Consult the department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 418 (3) Social Statistics II
Description: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.
Title: SOCI_V 420 (3) Sociology of the Environment
Description: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 423 (3) Sociology of Food
Description: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender. Food-related social movements will be included. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 425 (3) Urban Sociology
Description: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 430 (3) Global Citizenship
Description: Sociology approaches to global citizenship, including its contested nature and intellectual lineage.
Title: SOCI_V 433 (3-6) Directed Studies
Description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. And permission of the Department.
Title: SOCI_V 435 (3-6) International Service Learning
Description: International field placement normally for eight to ten weeks; pre-departure seminars (eight to twelve seminars or equivalent) with student presentation seminars upon return from the field.
Title: SOCI_V 440 (3) Economic Sociology
Description: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 441 (3) Society, Economy and Family
Description: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 440
Title: SOCI_V 442 (3) Families and Work
Description: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 442.
Title: SOCI_V 449 (6) Honours Tutorial
Description: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 461 (3) Political Sociology
Description: The social and economic bases of political power, including the study of the state, ideology, political movements, revolutions, and political violence. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 464 (3) Social Movements
Description: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 465 (3) Sociology of the Arts
Description: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 466 (3) Sociology of Education
Description: Examines the role of schooling in modern society including links with inequality, knowledge production, socialization and the economy. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 469 (3) Queer Theory and Politics
Description: Empirical expressions and political possibilities of queer theory. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.
Title: SOCI_V 470 (3) Sociology of Crime and Justice
Description: Critical examination of specific forms of crime in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 473 (3) Sociology of Mental Illness
Description: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 479 (3) Social Determinants of Health
Description: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 480 (3-6) Urban Ethnographic Field School (UEFS)
Description: Approximately 50 hours of volunteering and fieldwork based in community organizations with theoretical approaches to urban spaces. Students will engage in collaborative research while considering a range of theoretical and methodological approaches. Students may earn a maximum of 6 credits from ANTH 480 and SOCI 480. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. Or permission of the instructor(s). The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration.
Title: SOCI_V 490 (3) Contemporary Chinese Society
Description: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 495 (3-6) Advanced Studies in Sociology
Description: An intensive examination of selected topics in Sociology. Consult the department for this year's offerings. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.
Title: SOCI_V 500 (3) Foundations of Sociological Thought
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Title: SOCI_V 504 (3) Methodology of Social Inquiry
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 505 (3-6) Tutorial in Sociological Theory
Description: Prerequisite: One of SOCI 500, SOCI 501. The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 506 (3-6) Tutorial in Research Methods
Description: Prerequisite: One of SOCI 502, SOCI 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 507 (3-6) Advanced Theory Seminar
Description: Prerequisite: One of SOCI 500, SOCI 501. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 508 (3-6) Advanced Methods Seminar
Description: Prerequisite: One of SOCI 502, SOCI 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 509 (3-6) Sociology of the Environment
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 510 (3-6) Population, Community and Demography
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 511 (3) Cross-National Comparisons in the Social Sciences
Description: Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Equivalency: IAR 511 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 512 (3-6) Gender and Feminist Issues
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 513 (3) Theories About the Family
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 514 (3) Analyzing Quantitative Data in Sociology
Description: Prerequisite: SOCI 502 is a prerequisite for Sociology graduate students. A background in material such as that covered in SOCI 502 is highly recommended for all others. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 515 (3) Qualitative Data Analysis in Sociology
Description: Prerequisite: SOCI 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 520 (3-6) Law and Crime
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 530 (3-6) Social Change and Development
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 540 (3-6) Social Inequality
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 549 (6-12) Master's Thesis
Description: The credit value for this course will be determined in consultation with the student prior to the registration. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 562 (3-6) Mass Media and Communications
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 580 (3-6) Canadian Society
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 584 (3-6) Health, Illness and Society
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 590 (3-6) Seminar in an Ethnographic Area
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 596 (3-6) Political Sociology and Social Movements
Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Title: SOCI_V 598 (3-6) Directed Studies
